PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the taxes of all Australians will be used to finance a dam that would flood the Lower Gordon and Franklin Rivers in South-West Tasmania. Your petitioners declare that the intrinsic values of this area, and the provision of funds from the taxes of all Australians, for the destruction of this area of the National Estate and of world heritage value, does make this a national issue. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government take all possible steps, including financial and legal steps and fulfil its responsibilities under the Australian Heritage Act to prevent the destruction of this area of the National Estate, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Edwards,Mr Howard and Mr Barry Jones.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That record high interest rates are:
(a) Destroying the prospects of most young families seeking to purchase a home.
(b) Destroying the chances of national economic recovery.
(c) Contributing to the record number of business bankruptcies.
(d) Contributing to the highest unemployment since the great Depression.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia immediately reverse its policy of high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baume and Mr Les Johnson.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully compiled with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howard and Mr Barry Jones.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (H.S.C.) subject in secondary schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Department of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Jenkins and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: South Australian College of Advanced Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Australian Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of Australia showeth that:
Members of the Community are concerned and alarmed at staffing cuts within the South Australian College of Advanced Education.

Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the consequent deleterious effect these staffing cuts will have on the quality of educational programmes and the access of persons to these programmes at the South Australian College of Advanced Education.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia by this humble petition respectfully pray that the Australian Government provide additional funding to the South Australian College of Advanced Education to enable 1982 programmes and staff levels to be maintained and where needs exist, the resources of the College to be expanded to meet the requirements of the community of South Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as '' Australian Soldiers'' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that some single supporting parents are unfairly disadvantaged in having chosen to care for children full-time during the formative years, believing such care was essential to their well-being; and that women without dependent children, and who are under 50 years of age are not eligible for a continuing pension. These women have devoted their whole lives to their families and do not have skills relevant to the present employment situation. Their future prospects, with increasing age and length of time out of the workforce are a deterrent to employers. Skilled workers find it difficult to obtain employment and unskilled workers find it even more difficult. Unemployment benefit was not designed for long term usage and the low rate of payment plus the work tests over a long period of time lead to a general decline in the physical and mental health, with the result that the women are being placed on sickness benefits. Sickness benefits, however, were also designed for short term usage and is unable to provide security for these women.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:
(i) Amend the Social Services Act to reduce the age of eligibility for a Class B Widow pension from 50 to 40 years; and
(ii) Expand existing training schemes to include women taken off Supporting Parents' Benefit.
(iii) Provide rehabilitation for women with disabilities which preclude them from the paid work force.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Our opinion on paper: That ever since the early seventies, high interest rates of staggering magnitude! have made a complete mockery of justice, unparalleled in our time.

Resulting in the elimination of employment on a vast scale, in every phase of production causing house ejections, with mind effects and mental disturbances, leading to interrupted education, road toll and social disruption.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge politicians of all parties to nationally unite for the return of justice by using the powers vested in them to immediately and drastically reduce these destructive interest rates. Further and to this end a conscience vote is essential, if justice is to be served.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That in recent years thousands of families have lost their homes, the building industry and employment is at an all time low, with social disruption from continued increases in interest rates.
All this, in our opinion, is due to extortionate interest rates that have passed the bounds of all reason and void of equity and moral justification.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board, also in the political arena a conscience vote is essential.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The heart-rending loss of homes by home purchasers, due to an expanding holocaust of interest rates caused by, and to quote the manager of a leading bank (26.4.81) ''with the growing competition for savings, depositors are looking for higher interest returns on deposits. In order to retain our depositors and to meet the increased costs payable on deposits and operating expenses, it is necessary to raise income from loans of all types, including house loans.''

Therefore it becomes transparently clear that the constant edging up of interest rates for investors by banks, lending institutions, and banking consortiums are collectively responsible for the monetary explosion, lack of employment and all that that entails and is causing grave social disruption to hundreds of thousands. Behind it all, the absence of control that is now politically essential in the interest of justice and fair distribution of burden .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Miss Boey Fong Boh
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. We, the undersigned call for the concern of all members of Parliament that our country, Australia, is not willing to consider granting Miss Boey Fong Boh permanent residency.

2. Miss Boey Fong Boh is a very warm, intelligent, kind and considerate person who has endeared herself to many people. Her residency here would make her a very much accepted citizen who also has many skills to share.

3. Miss Boh has endured a great deal of hardship-re: her Paternity Suit and has come through this ordeal a very strong person. Her child, Chantelle Ling Boh born 4.11.81, is very much Australian by birth and physical appearance and has every right to remain in the country of her birth and we strongly request her mother be granted Permanent Residency.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N .H.S. and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whaling Protection Act, 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale by-products, and
2. The Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the International Banning of Whaling,
3. Then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal by-products, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. Through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an International ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products , and support an International ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that Australia Council funding for the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has been entirely cut for 1983.

The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has made an important contribution to the cultural and artistic life of the Australian community for the past eight years taking innovative and original theatre to sections of the community who would not normally attend live theatre performances.
The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland is the only theatre company in Australia which consistently presents theatre of social comment and tours nationally every year.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will resolve to ask the Australia Council to reverse its decision in respect to the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That Family Radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e., Christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representation.
That prime time access to existing broadcasts by Christian groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing.
That, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM broadcasting licence.
That there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane.
That satisfactory fulfillment of the aims of family radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence.

That Family Radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its development, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established.

That there is an urgent need for the kind of service and support that Family Radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of integrated programming proposed by the company under a full-time licence.
And that pruned government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as originally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will support Family Radio's application for a broadcasting licence and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not protecting family home buyers from the severe effects of increased and increasing rates by interest on home mortgage loans. Together with causing a drastic slump in the home building and associated industries.

Your Petitioners, therefore, pray that Parliament take immediate and positive action by a 1 per cent reduction in Savings Bank interest rates to avert any further effects of increases in interest rates on home mortgage loans which cause detrimental financial, social and psychological pressures on families, and in many cases, positive hardship
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that the decision to make pensioners and financially disadvantaged persons complete a declaration form before obtaining concessional and free pharmaceuticals is both an unnecessary harassment of the aged and those on low incomes and a time consuming and therefore costly burden for chemists.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government demonstrates some concern for the integrity and welfare of the aged by withdrawing the decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhumane manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia (UEGA) has suggested sites in the heavily populated region of South-East Queensland for the development of a uranium enrichment plant;
(2) that the Commonwealth Government has approved, in principle, UEGA's suggestions, without consultation with the residents of the area; and
(3) that UEGA and the Commonwealth Government will conduct feasibility studies into the plant, but no confirmation has been made of a study into the safety of the plant.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives condemns the Government for approving, in principle, UEGA's suggestions to establish a uranium enrichment plant in the heavily populated area of South-East Queensland and requires that the Government (1) conducts a poll of all South- East Queensland residents to determine whether they give assent to the plant and (2) conducts a comprehensive and independent study of the safety of the uranium enrichment plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantages in employment, education , accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance.

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Badgery Creek, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
No airport for Badgery's Creek or its surrounding districts and your petitioners duly will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia in the electorate of Kooyong respectfully submit:
1. That the Federal Government's plans to reduce its share of funding for pre- school education be reconsidered
2. That the Government recognise that any decrease in funding will lead to sharp fee increases and will deny many children access to pre-school education.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Benefits: Private Enterprise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our concern that:
1. The Income Tax Assessment Act (the Act) and its administration is inadequate in providing retirement benefits for employees in private enterprise;
2. The Commissioner of Taxation (Commissioner) denies deductions necessary to index retirement pensions;
3. Deductions for the self-employed and employed are inadequate;
4. The Commissioner has exercised his discretion improperly by negating a choice the Act allows on investment in Government Securities;
5. The Commissioner's constant alterations to guidelines and lack of communication has created great uncertainty.
6. The Commissioner is acting arbitrarily, and without proper notice in restricting trustee's investments with employers;
7. The Commissioner seeks to apply new actuarial guidelines restrospectively to July 1981.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, take action to remedy these inadequacies and in particular we pray that action be taken:
(i) To ensure that the Commissioner exercises his discretion only with proper regard to legal principles;
(ii) To ensure that the Commissioner does not delegate to auditors part of his function of administering the Act;
(iii) To enact legislation allowing proper levels of retirement benefits to be provided;
(iv) To ensure that retirement benefits are regulated by a Department with a primarily social welfare function.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Philippines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain undersigned persons (citizens of Australia) shows-concern and dismay that Fr Brian Gore, an Australian citizen and missionary priest in the Phillipines is charged with subversion, possession of explosives and of inciting rebellion, warrants of arrest pertaining to which have been issued and were served on October 18, 1982.

Your petitioners therefore pray that you do all in your power to urge the Phillipine authorities to cease harassment of Fr. Gore and to allow him to continue his missionary work; furthermore that Fr. Gore be allowed his right to legal advice and representation and of access at all times to his friends and religious colleagues.

PETITION.TITLE: Philippines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certian undersigned persons (electors of the Division of Moore) shows concern and dismay that Father Brian Gore, an Australian citizen and missionary priest in the Philippines is charged with subversion, possession of explosives and of inciting rebellion, warrants of arrest pertaining to which have been issued and served on 18 October, 1982.

Your petitioners therefore pray that you do all in your power to urge the Philippine authorities to cease harassment of Father Gore and to allow him to continue his missionary work without threat or fear of arrest, furthermore, as a warrant of arrest has been served, that father Gore be allowed his right to legal advice and representation and of access at all times to his friends and religious colleagues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medical Services at Remote Nursing Posts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and the members of the House Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of the state of Western Australia respectfully petition:
That the Federal Government amend the Health Insurance Act to allow medical services at nursing posts to be eligible for hospital benefits.

In the remote and sparsely populated areas of Australia, particularly Western Australia, there are many communities that cannot on an economic or population need basis, justify the provision of a complete hospital service. In these areas nursing posts have been established to provide first aid and primary nursing care services to local residents and travellers.

Since these premises do not meet the criteria laid down in Section 24 of the Health Insurance Act, they no longer attract hospital benefits from health insurance organisations for treatment recieved at them.

This provision of the Act places all people in remote areas at a considerable disadvantage to people living in cities or larger centres. We ask therefore that the relevant Section of the Act be immediately amended so that recipients of aid at nursing posts are eligible for health benefits. The present circumstances, although probably caused by an administrative oversight are particularly inequitable.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Government Economic Policies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned electors of the Division of Isaacs respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's economic policies are causing undue hardship to millions of Australians.
2. The unemployment problem constitutes a national crisis with farreaching economic and social consequences.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
1. The Government reverses its economic policies and alleviates the hardships faced by Australian families.
2. Begin a job creation programme in both the private and public sector.
3. Extend Australian training and retraining programmes.
4. Implement a comprehensive manpower policy to meet Australia's future needs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and members of the House of representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned electors of the Division of Isaacs respectfully showeth:

1. That the proposal to charge local telephone calls on a time basis will increase telephone bills, thereby disadvantaging those people who could least afford it, such as pensioners and other low-income earners.
2. That the proposal to change Telecom into a company would be the first step towards selling Telecom to private enterprise.
3. That the proposal to sell parts of Telecom's more profitable operations can only lead to increased charges, particularly for domestic and country services.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government guarantees:
1. That local telephone calls will continue to be charged on a per call basis.
2. That Telecom will remain a Statutory Authority.
3. That no part of Telecom will be sold, and that Telecom's more profitable operations must continue to subsidise domestic and country services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: East Killara: Postal Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Bradfield respectfully showeth:
That the Post Office needs to open a sub-agency at East Killara for the following reasons:
1. The nearest Post Office is 2 km distant at Killara.
2. Public transport in the area is inadequate in business hours for the general public to be able to obtain normal Post Office services.
3. Many residents of the district are elderly and cannot drive a car. Some are three km from Killara Post Office.

4. No other suburb within the district has such inadequate service by the Post Office. Each suburb has a local sub-agency within one km approximately and the local population has grown considerably in recent years.
5. Suitable premises are available within the local East Killara shopping centre.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective post office service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly and commercially in the area.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned students and staff of the James Cook University of North Queensland respectfully showeth that:
1. Failure to extend eligibility under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) and increase the value of TEAS allowances to cover basic living costs will
(a) continue to deter thousands of Australians from entering tertiary institutions.
(b) continue to force many of Australia's tertiary students to live in a state of dire poverty.
2. Introduction of a comprehensive student loans scheme will
(a) restrict access to education because people from poorer backgrounds will be deterred from studying by the prospect of incurring large debts.
(b) disadvantage women because on average they earn less and have a higher unemployment rate and disadvantage mature age students because they generally already have large financial commitments.
(c) undermine TEAS because government statements indicate TEAS will be further downgraded if loans are introduced.
(d) distort educational choices because students will tend to choose shorter courses and will not go on with postgraduate study.
3. Introduction of fees for post graduate and second degree students will
(a) deter many tertiary students from undertaking of continuing such courses of study for purely financial reasons.
(b) result in the limiting of Australia's capacity to cope with change because fewer people will upgrade their degrees or broaden their fields of knowledge.
(c) seriously undermine Australia's Research effort.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
(i) introduce legislation to extend eligibility under TEAS and increase TEAS allowances to cover basic living costs.
(ii) reject the introduction of a student loans scheme.
(iii) reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Public Transport Interchange
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of the Australian Capital Territory shows:
That the exclusion of Taxis from the Civic Passenger Transport interchange is an unjust decision and places hardship on the sick, elderly, disabled and the public in general.
Your petitioners therefore pray that immediate action be taken to permit Taxis to use the Civic Public Transport Interchange.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Visiting Practitioner Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain residents and friends of Swan Cottage Homes, Bentley, Western Australia, respectfully showeth that:
Residents are concerned to continue to enjoy the convenience and quality of care offered by visiting medical practitioners at the surgery and in their homes .
Most of the residents of Swan Cottage Homes are either physically or financially handicapped and find it almost impossible to travel to doctors' surgeries.

The loss of the visiting practitioner service will provide a vacuum for which the Government is directly and solely responsible, and shows no regard by the Government for the welfare of the elderly and infirm who in their youth fought for and built Australia into what it is today.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government should withdraw those Item Numbers in the Health Act pertaining to the visiting practitioner service in nursing home complexes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present the Committee's Report on the ANZUS Alliance, incorporating two dissenting reports, together with the transcript of evidence and four submissions received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 8 September 1981, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence passed a resolution referring to its Sub-Committee A, the Sub- committee on the Pacific Basin, the term of reference: Australian-United States relations. The Sub-Committee was chaired by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) and conducted a wide-ranging inquiry into all the major aspects of Australian-United States relations, including foreign policy, security and defence matters as well as economic and cultural relations. I thank those individuals and government departments who spent time and effort preparing written submissions and giving oral evidence before the Sub-committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The focus of this report is Australia's long standing security relationship with the United States, as embodied in the ANZUS treaty. This report has already been tabled in the Senate and I will not repeat the tabling statement to the House. ANZUS is an important part of a wider Australian-United States relationship which, during the last 30 years, has become increasingly more multifaceted and remains Australia's singlemost important external relationship. Chapter 1 of the report traces the history of the ANZUS pact. In chapter 2, the significance of ANZUS in the light of past events, including the Malaysian- Indonesian confrontation in the early 1960s, is discussed, as are also current Australian and American perceptions of ANZUS and its role, including the extent to which, realistically, Australia could expect assistance under the terms of the treaty should this country ever face a serious threat to its security.

The Committee considers that the mutual security provisions of the ANZUS treaty together represent a stronger assurance of military assistance in the event of an attack on Australian territory than a commitment merely to consult. At the same time, the Committee emphasises that official United States statements of its defence thinking in relation to the Asian Pacific region, as well as United States expectations of Australia's role within the framework of ANZUS, indicate that the United States view of its role in the region precludes direct military involvement except in an extreme situation. I think this position reflects the Guam doctrine. The Committee believes that the official Australian view of ANZUS acknowledges this.

In chapter 3, the Committee discusses the benefits and costs of ANZUS. There was Press comment on the report when it was tabled in the Senate about Australian-Indonesian relations. The report stresses that no major threat to Australia's security has emerged or is likely to emerge in the short term. On page 65, a paragraph concerning Indonesia states, in part:
Indonesia is one local power well-placed to pose a potential threat . . .

We should amend that sentence to read 'geographically well placed' to explain the meaning of that paragraph. That paragraph reflects the evidence presented to the Sub-Committee. It discusses a purely hypothetical potential situation that could develop. It does not refer specifically to a potential direct threat from Indonesia but to the possibility that at some stage in the future a regional conflict could develop, such as the Malaysian-Indonesian confrontation in the 1960s, which in turn could affect Australia's interests. I think that has been interpreted out of context by the media. The threat has to be read in the context of the previous report of the Committee entitled 'Threats to Australia's Security'.

In chapter 3, the Committee concludes that the Australian-United States relationship is, and continues to be, mutually advantageous. It also points out that the United States should take seriously Australia's views on matters of mutual concern where we may have a separate national perspective. In this regard , the Committee endorses the assessment of the Department of Foreign Affairs. The United States adopts this position. In chapter 4, the Committee evaluated what is perhaps the most significant concern in relation to ANZUS that is, the future of the alliance. The report points out that the stability of Australia's own strategic environment is linked in no small measure to the effective involvement of United States interest and policies throughout the region. The Committee believes that differences between the United States and Australia will exist from time to time but that the management of these differences is likely to be conducted in an atmosphere which favours accommodation. That is certainly the history of these matters.

The Committee's conclusion is, therefore, that the ANZUS alliance remains both useful and necessary and that Australia should remain within its framework. The report emphasises that the security links between Australia and the United States spring from shared values, compatible institutions and objectives and continuing popular support within the Australian community for ANZUS and the wider Western alliance. I think that ANZUS and the relations with the United States are part of one relationship but the whole United States-Australian relationship, of which ANZUS is a part, is part of a wider set of relationships, and that is Australia as a committed member of the Western alliance. ANZUS arose out of the Australian-United States relationship. The relationship did not arise out of ANZUS. I think that is an important point to make. It is a flexible and changing relationship, and that is its strength.

The reference is a continuing one. The Committee will consider other aspects of the reference. One aspect I would wish to look at in future is Australia's relations with the United States Congress. The Australian Government enjoys excellent relations, based on mutual respect, with the United States President and Administration. But the United States does not have a Westminster system and the United States Government Administration is not formed from and does not arise out of the Congress; it is separate from it. The executive and legislative power are separate in that country. In our system, of course, they are not. This has led us basically to ignore the importance of the United States Congress in Australian-United States relations. I believe Australia has to work to improve future relations between the Australian Parliament and the United States Congress. The Congress will be receptive to the work that needs to be done. I recently spoke to our Ambassador in Washington, Sir Robert Cotton, and I think he understands the problem well. There needs to be a greater manpower effort put in on Capitol Hill by our embassy in Washington. A mechanism needs to be developed for a permanent and regular exchange of views between members of the Australian Senate and House of Representatives and their United States counterparts. This can only be in the interests of greater understanding between our two nations. In conclusion, I thank Dr Edvi-Illes and Mr Dan Barton of the Committee's secretariat for their assistance and hard work in the preparation of the report. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Without wishing to traverse the contents of the report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence concerning the ANZUS Alliance, I wish to add something to it. Just as important as the actual terms of the ANZUS treaty are the potential psychological factors of any changes which would have an effect, to my mind, on world peace which, currently, to a large extent is due to the balance of power between the two super powers. The greatest threat to peace would be a belief by the Soviet Union that it could win a quick war. Similarly, in the late 1930s-1938-39-Hitler thought we would not stand by Poland following the Munich agreement, the invasion of Czechoslovakia and the Hitler-Stalin pact. A decision by Australia to cancel ANZUS would be seen by the Soviet Union as a signal that its drive to the south, whether from Vietnam or through Iran, would not be opposed. In fact, such action by Australia and New Zealand could well persuade the United States population to become more isolationist and to allow the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to speed up its imperialist drive which has been going on ever since the last war. If this happened it would ultimately lead to war. It is, therefore, important that our signals to the Soviet Union are clear. This also applies to other allies of the United States such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries.

SPEECH.PARA: In the general debate on matters of neutralism, unilateral disarmament and alliances with the United States, I shall read into Hansard part of a speech made recently by James Callaghan, the last Labour Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. According to the London Times, on 18 November 1982, in an address to the Cardiff Fabian Society, he said:

. . . a Labour Government should retain Polaris, allow cruise, keep the American bases, and concentrate its attention on multilateral disarmament talks, comprehensive test-ban negotiations and the pursuit of non-proliferation.
The article continued:

'Why should we unilaterally give away any bargaining counters whilst negotiations are in progress?' Mr Callaghan said. 'To do so would be to hand to the Soviet Union something valuable with no prospect of anything in exchange. The Soviet Union would say ''thank you'' and pocket it.'
According to the article, Mr Callaghan said that some say:

Abandon our nuclear weapons, close down our nuclear bases in this country, and send the Americans back home. If we do, goes the argument, we shall be safe from attack and, as a bonus, other countries will be so impressed that they will follow our lead.
The article goes on to state:
Such a policy was attractive, but wrong, and Mr Callaghan questioned whether Britain could retain its self-respect, given such a policy, if it continued to rely on Nato nuclear protection.
Mr Callaghan is reported as asking:
How could we escape attack in any future war, by any weapons the enemy might think necessary to reduce us?
He is quoted as saying:

Unilateral disarmament does not offer a way out. The only real safety for British people is through collective security and multilateral agreement to disarm the nuclear and conventional arsenals of both sides.
The article goes on to state:

He also said that any unilateral action, which would be certain to damage Anglo -American friendship, might eventually lead to the 'unravelling of NATO on the mainland of Europe'. If America was provoked into isolationism, the alliance would be destabilised, and it would even be possible that West Germany might be forced to seek closer links with East Germany.

He said that everyone shared the unilateralists' horror of nuclear war. But he concluded: 'The task for a Labour Government is to secure a series of comprehensive multilateral agreements to achieve our ends. That way lies safety for the British people, and for the world.'

Similarly, if we send the wrong signals to the world by changing our attitude to ANZUS-I am not suggesting that any significant proportion of the Australian population would want to do that-some of the weaker countries in our area might be prepared to do deals with the Soviet Union or the Soviet Union's satellite of Vietnam. I think it is terribly important to consider that matter of signals and the matter of making it quite clear that we stand by ANZUS. It is in our interests. It is in the interests of the United States. I think it is much more in our interests than it is in the interests of the United States. Most importantly, it is in the interests of the free world and people who want to continue to be able to make decisions as to their lifestyle freely, in the sort of democratic pattern which we are used to and which obviously is not applicable to the Soviet Union and its satellites. Therefore, it is terribly important for us to continue to emphasise our commitment to the ANZUS alliance.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I table the annual report for 1981-82 of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 5.59 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I must confess that I was away during the consideration by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of the report on the ANZUS Alliance. First of all I want to associate myself with two items of the dissenting report. I agree with one of the statements in the introduction to the report which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia's basic objective is to fulfil its commitment to the Alliance, with due regard to our national interest and the maintenance of our national sovereignty.

I note the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) who is again a member of the Ministry and who will recall some of the observations I have made over the years about the North West Cape agreement and the abject derogation of Australian sovereignty in that agreement, particularly in the exchange of letters between the United States Ambassador, Mr Battle, and the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Sir Garfield Barwick. So Australia has not always maintained this national interest and notion of sovereignty in our associations with the United States. We all remember the very demeaning slogan that was mouthed by one of our Prime Ministers about being 'All the way with LBJ '.

What I want to raise tonight is what I perceive as the tone of the report which gives an unreal expectation about the alliance. I believe that from the viewpoint of both sides of Parliament and of Australia this is dangerous. I quote United States Under-Secretary of State, Mr Averell Harriman who, in 1963, when the Australian Government of the day was discussing with the United States Administration the question of confrontation and what would be the impact of loss of life or confrontation between the Indonesians and Australians, said:
Defence agreements are not precise as to military movements or diplomatic activity. There is always a grey area.
I also recall the following words of President Nixon:
Our interests must shape our commitments rather than the other way around.

I point out to the House that we should not delude ourselves that ANZUS is a watertight commitment by the United States. I think it is only in the field of foreign affairs that we recognise that the United States will not assume responsibilities it does not see as being in its interests. The report details periods when Australia was concerned about the United States commitment. I need only to mention the confrontation involved in the Indonesians' claim to West Irian. I think we should look at those sections of the report very carefully, and should heed the experiences we went through in that period. Successive United States administrations have made it clear that possible commitments under ANZUS can arise only in the context of the central power balance. This follows from the Guam statements of President Nixon that United States allies are expected to handle in their own way regional disputes that are not associated with the central power balance. I want to raise a particular reservation in the report-unfortunately I was not in the discussions of the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee to raise this-which appears on page 67. The report states:
The Committee does not see any distortion of Australia's defence policy resulting from the ANZUS Alliance.

I think that if one examines Australia's role over the years one finds that Australia has been a junior partner and has supplied military aid to both the United Kingdom-Great Britain in those days-and the United States, where our force structure was in fact shaped by the alliance. We slotted in our units of the Army, Navy and Air Force to a larger command. They were reponsible for the command and also the logistics of our forces. I believe that if we are dealing with Australia as having a self-reliant defence force we have to make decisions that are outside any alliance that we may have. I think this is brought home to us in the sense that the United States expects us to do that. I fear that over the last couple of years there have been indications that the Government has moved away from this notion of self-reliance and is again taking the part of a junior partner in the alliance operations.

I am not happy about the sections of the report dealing with the Indian Ocean. We should keep in mind our interests in relation to the north-west Indian Ocean are essentially different, and can be different, from those of other countries because we are Australians. That is an area which is, in fact, closer to Europe than to Australia. I believe that in determining our own defence force structure we cannot commit ourselves outside our competence to carry out commitments. Our first function-I believe this is a function that the United States expects of us -is to be able to look after our own affairs in our area. I associate with these remarks the attitude of the present Secretary of the Department of Defence who has pointed out that we cannot undertake commitments well outside our direct area of influence. I think this is important to consider in terms of our commitment to ANZUS.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peacock, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to repeal section 14 of that Act. Section 14 of the Act imposes an obligation on the Minister not to take action which is inconsistent with the obligations of Australia under international agreements relating to trade. The repeal of this section is principally designed to remove for practical purposes the grounds for any application to the Australian courts raising the issue of Australia's non- compliance with international agreements, including the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade codes and any bilaterial agreements, relating to anti-dumping and countervailing duty action.

The provision of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act enable the Government to take anti-dumping and contervailing duty action against imports. Both actions are designed to offset export prices which are not established on a fair commercial basis. Australia is a signatory to the GATT, and the related codes which establish rules of conduct for anti-dumping and countervailing actions. The codes, which elaborate on the relevant provisions of the GATT, were part of the outcome of the multilateral Trade Negotiations, Tokyo Round, concluded in 1979. Australia acceded to the Subsidies and Countervailing Duties Code on 21 September 1982 and to the Anti-Dumping Code on 21 October 1982.

The codes require that signatories must take all necessary steps to ensure that their domestic legislation conforms with the provisions of the codes. The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act was amended in 1981 so that it conforms with the codes. Anti-dumping or countervailing duties cannot be imposed unless it is determined by the relevant authority in the importing country that the goods in question have been dumped-that is, exported at less than normal prices in the country of export or subsidised and as a result an industry in the importing country has been injured or threatened with injury. The codes also limit the extent of countervailing or anti-dumping action to an amount equal to the amount of subsidy or of dumping or the extent to which injury is occurring, whichever is the less.

Where a preliminary affirmative finding of dumping or subsidisation is made by the Department of Industry and Commerce as the relevant authority and there is evidence of material injury or threat of material injury to the domestic industry, the GATT anti-dumping and subsidies and countervailing duties codes permit the taking of provisional action in the form of securities which in Australia are taken under the provisions of section 42 of the Customs Act. The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act has facilitated proceedings for injunctive relief in these matters before the Federal Court of Australia. The related Customs Securities (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill which I will introduce shortly contains a provision to remove from the scope of that Act decisions to take securities under the Customs Act as provisional anti-dumping and countervailing measures. That provision will supersede the regulations with similar effect introduced on 24 November 1982.

In the injunction proceedings before the Court exporters of goods to Australia have used the provisions of section 14 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping Act) as the basis for arguing that the method by which the Department proceeds to the decision to require provisional anti-dumping and provisional countervailing measures is contrary to Australia's international obligations. Whilst the Department meets the requirements of the codes in principle these arguments have nevertheless enabled interim injunctions to be obtained. As a consequence, the Department has been prevented from taking provisional securities and this has operated to the detriment of Australian industry.

The world wide economic recession has led to a dramatic increase in the number of dumping and countervailing complaints in Australia. The Government is therefore concerned that there should be no impediment to taking quick and effective action to combat unfair trading practices which operate to the detriment of Australian industry. The repeal of section 14 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, as proposed by this Bill, will not affect Australia's adherence to the relevant international obligations. The Government's view is that issues concerning Australia's obligations under the international agreements relating to anti-dumping and countervailing duty action are more appropriately considered within the context of the dispute settlement provisions of the particular agreements rather than in the Australian courts. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peacock, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is twofold. It amends the Customs Act to place beyond doubt that securities may be validly taken under section 42 of that Act for the purposes of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. It also amends the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to remove from the scope of that Act decisions made under section 42 of the Customs Act to require and take securities in respect of duty that may be payable under the Customs Tariff (Anti -Dumping) Act. The Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Act is the legislation which enables the Government to take anti-dumping and countervailing duty action against imports. This action is designed to offset export prices which are not established on a fair commercial basis.

Where a preliminary affirmative finding of dumping or subsidisation is made by the Department of Industry and Commerce and there is evidence of material injury or threat of material injury to the domestic industry, provisional action in the form of securities may be taken under the provisions of section 42 of the Customs Act. The securities are held in accordance with the time limits specified in the Customs Act until, after inquiry, a final decision is made as to whether dumping or countervailing duties are warranted. If the final decision is in the affirmative the securities held are adjusted to the amount of the duty to be imposed. If the decision is that dumping or countervailing duty is not warranted the securities are returned to depositors.

As a consequence of litigation in the Federal Court the Department has been restrained from taking provisional anti-dumping and countervailing securities in respect of the importation of certain goods into Australia. It has been argued in these proceedings that the terms of section 42 of the Customs Act do not authorise the taking of security for the purpose of protecting Australian industry. The amendments in Clause 4 of the Bill provide an express link between section 42 of the Customs Act and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. This is proposed to remove any doubt as to the validity of requiring securities under the Customs Act for the purposes of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act.

In my second reading speech relating to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982, I explained how exporters of goods to Australia have been able to use the existing law to prevent the Department from taking provisional securities. The provisions of clause 6 of the Bill are designed to minimise the opportunities to prevent the taking of such securities. Under this clause decisions relating to the taking of the securities will be exempted from the scope of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

Regulations with similar effect to this clause became operative on 24 November 1982. The provisions in this bill will, however, supersede those regulations and it is the Government's intention that the regulations will be repealed after this Bill receives royal assent. The Government believes that the removal from judicial review of decisions on provisional securities is essential if anti- dumping and countervailing measures are to be efffective in combating unfair international trading practices which operate to the detriment of Australian industry. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (LOANS GUARANTEE AND SUBSIDY) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide the legislative basis for the implementation of the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme which will be introduced early in 1983. The Bill provides for the Commonwealth to subsidise the interest charged by banks on approved loans and for the Commonwealth to give guarantees to banks that it will repay outstanding debts on approved loans within prescribed limits. The Bill also covers the eligibility conditions applying to loans.

The Tertiary Student Loans Scheme will enable full time tertiary students who are Australian citizens or permanent residents to borrow between $500 and $1,000 , per annum from banks to help pay for their education and living expenses while studying. Students will be able to borrow up to $8,000 over the total period of their study.

Many full time students will be eligible for approved loans by virtue of their entitlement to benefits under various Commonwealth student assistance schemes. These schemes are: The Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards Scheme, the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme known as TEAS, the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme and the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme. The Tertiary Student Loans Scheme will provide an additional source of support for eligible students receiving benefits under these schemes. Other full time students will qualify for loans providing they satisfy a simple means test, the details of which have already been announced in the Budget context. These details will be prescribed in regulations.

The Government has demonstrated its strong continuing support for student assistance schemes by its decision to increase substantially allowance levels and relax means tests for 1983. The loans scheme will provide another option for students. The interest rate to apply to loans will be the maximum rate permissible for advances by banks of less than $100,000-currently 14.5 per cent per annum-reduced by 5 percentage points by a Commonwealth subsidy. The Commonwealth will provide banks with guarantees amounting to $50m per annum on approved loans but the banks will be expected to take all reasonable steps to obtain repayments from defaulting borrowers before the Commonwealth honours guarantees.

The scheme will be administered by the Commonwealth Department of Education in conjunction with the banks and tertiary institutions, and the detailed terms and conditions for approved loans will be prescribed in regulations. Funds to meet payments by the Commonwealth of interest subsidies and the repayments of any defaulted loans will be provided for through the general appropriation legislation. For this financial year the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1982-83 provides $150,000 for these purposes. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Scholes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments-
No. 1-Page 14, clause 26, proposed sub-section 39A (1), lines 15 and 16, leave out ', whether or not specified in Schedule 18,'.

No. 2-Page 14, clause 26, proposed sub-section 39A (1), lines 18 and 19, leave out 'a college of advanced education specified in Schedule 18 and situated in the same State as the first-mentioned institution', insert 'a university or a college of advanced education situated in the same State as the first-mentioned institution, and at least one of those institutions is specified in Schedule 18' .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

Honourable members will recall that on the advice of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission the Government has required certain colleges of advanced education to enter into amalgamation arrangements aimed at bringing about larger consolidated institutions. Such institutions are better able to handle problems associated with change and can offer students a wider range of educational choice and a higher quality of educational program. Some economies of scale also exist, although such considerations were not the primary reasons behind the Government's decision to require amalgamations. Twenty-six of the 30 institutions concerned have now entered into acceptable arrangements. The Government believes that these amalgamations will be successful and that higher education will be strengthened in the long term.

There are four colleges yet to finalise acceptable arrangements. These are the Armidale, Newcastle and Milperra colleges of advanced education and the Hawthorn Institute of Education. In respect of Armidale and Newcastle it is expected that the New South Wales Government will legislate for the amalgamation of each college of advanced education with the relevant local university following the passage of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill through the Commonwealth Parliament. The nature of the final amalgamation arrangements has yet to be determined in respect of Milperra and Hawthorn.

The Government has recognised that for maximum effectiveness the precise arrangements for amalgamations should reflect local circumstances and are, therefore, best determined at the local level. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill requires the Minister for Education to provide funds for the operation of institutions in 1983 only when he is satisfied that suitable amalgamation arrangements are in hand. Essentially, the amendment which I have moved enables a broader intepretation to be taken as to what constitutes a satisfactory amalgamation. In this respect it seeks to take account of the latest thinking of the State governments concerned as to how the Commonwealth's requirements may be met for the two remaining institutions. In summary, the amendment recognises that a suitable amalgamation might be affected by an institution assuming certain of the teaching responsibilities of another institution. Such an arrangement might well meet the Commonwealth's requirements in a way which had not been anticipated earlier in the process. The amendment, therefore, ensures that education rationale remains the central concern of the amalgamation exercise.

As foreshadowed by the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, during the debate in another place on the Bill, the Government's decision on a wage pause for the next 12 months will, of course, contain any increases in the cost of running tertiary institutions. Under the Government's prospective cost adjustment arrangements, the sums of money specified in the Schedules to the Bill include an allowance for wage and salary increases in 1983 in accordance with earlier decisions. Following the Premiers Conference yesterday, there will now be savings flowing from the wages pause and the Government will, therefore, restrict the rate of advances under the Bill as from the beginning of 1983 to reflect this. A similar course of action will be taken in relation to grants for both government and non-government schools. These reductions in the rate of advances will be formalised by amending legislation during 1983. In the light of the outcome of yesterday's Premiers Conference the Government is giving consideration to spending the consequent savings available to the Commonwealth, including savings with respect to this matter, on worthwhile programs which employ labour. I commend the amendments to the House.
Amendments agreed to.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
