Ordered that the message be taken into consideration forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed:
(1) That the House concurs in the resolution transmitted to the House in message No. 323 of the Senate, viz.:
(a) That the following matters be referred to the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings for inquiry and report:
(i) the televising of the proceedings of the Houses of the Parliament and their committees in the new Parliament House; and

(ii) the continuous and simultaneous radio broadcasting of both Houses of the Parliament. (b) That the Committee, for any purposes related to this inquiry, have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to hold up the House for very long. The matter before the House is for a reference to the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings of which consideration will take place . I believe that before members of this House or the other House commit themselves to what seems to be a good idea of televising parliamentary proceedings they should look at what the results of televising the Parliament will be, if it is on anything like the basis on which broadcasting takes place. There are areas which are televised and where parliamentary proceedings are recorded and made available to the Press for its use. Before too many members run away with the attractiveness of television in the Parliament I suggest that the three or four honourable members who are in the Parliament at the moment have a look around and see the sort of camera picture that could be picked up here.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution in relation to the duration of the House of Representatives, the holding of elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives and the appointment and termination of the appointment of Ministers of State. The Bill has already passed the Senate. It was the subject of an amendment in that chamber. It is a Bill that was proposed by Senator Gareth Evans, a member of the Australian Labor Party. I say at the outset that of course this is a Bill that has been proposed in the knowledge that we are in opposition. However, we hope that the Government of the day will agree to some constitutional amendments. Even though we are in opposition we hope that the proposal the Government will agree to in the Bill, a fixed term for the House of Representatives. It is a reasonable and rational proposal to be submitted to the people for approval, as it must be if there is to be a change.

When Labor becomes the Government of Australia it will offer a much wider package of constitutional reform. Our party for some time has been urging that the people of Australia have a chance to improve the Constitution. We urge the Government to bring it out of the horse and buggy days of the last century into the modern era in which we have to face national and international problems that were in no way envisaged at the time the Constitution was drafted-the 1890s. We hope to get not only the politicians involved in conventions and discussions as to the best way to improve our Constitution but also the rest of the people of Australia. They should be involved and asked as to how they see their charter being brought up to date.

For example, a new Constitution ought to have a Bill of Rights in it. In any rational democracy the people are entitled to have rights as against a government. Those rights ought to be enshrined in the Constitution. Even though this is a first step it is a very excellent step. The Senate has approved of that idea in the form of the Bill that we are now to deal with. I was reminded by Senator Gareth Evans that the Government in the Senate opposed the Bill at all its stages. Nevertheless in the Senate, in the form in which it has now been received by us, it received very substantial cross-party support. The Labor Party was joined at the third reading not only by the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine but also by six members of the Liberal Party. Also the Bill at all its stages had strong and consistent support in newspapers and from respected people interested in constitutional reform.

The Bill has no political content in the sense that it might be of advantage or disadvantage to one side or the other. The real thrust of this legislation is to give some stability to the House of Representatives. Section 28 of the Constitution presently provides that the House of Representatives, the people's House, is entitled to remain for a period of three years. Of course, that has not happened. There has been the inevitability of having to deal with a hostile Senate. Prime Ministers, because of their own personal whims, might wish to cut short the normal life cycle of the House of Representatives.

It is a matter of record that since the Second World War the average life of the House of Representatives has not been three years but two years four months. As one of those members left over from the Whitlam era I remind the House that when we were elected to Government in 1972 we faced continual threats of having to go back to the people simply because we had a hostile Senate. In fact we faced elections in 1974 and 1975. As Government members knew-we did not-the House of Representatives was dissolved early in 1977.The dissolution in 1977 was obviously related to the fact that the Opposition at the time was going to change its leadership or something of that nature, and it created dreadful problems for our society. It virtually destroyed the reputation of one man who held the office of Governor-General and, of course, it also affected the person who held the position of Chief Justice. Incredible damage was done not to those people as such but to the very society which we are trying to suggest to the people is strong, efficient and fair. We are very mindful of the fact that if the people elect a government according to the Constitution-for three years-that government ought to remain in office for three years and ought not to be removed by some political force, which is the normal political force of an Opposition.

The Senate was originally conceived as a House that would not be in any way aligned, motivated or affected by party politics. That was an unreal and idealistic view. To their credit, everybody has a political position. Senators are now part and parcel of the professional political arena of the Parliament. They come to party meetings, they take part in party discussions and they abide by party deliberations. It is nonsensical to think that an Opposition in the House of Representatives would not exercise its political muscle and power in the Senate when it had the numbers there because the method of election and the timing of Senate elections are different. This Bill is proposed in the savage knowledge that what happened in 1974-75 should never be repeated. But it can be repeated, because the Bill deals only with a fixed term for the House of Representatives. The term envisaged by the Bill is three years and elections would be held on a fixed date, namely, the third Saturday in November. The life of a parliament would expire in the previous October. There have to be exceptions to that. So naturally and properly the Bill provides that if a government no longer has the confidence of the House it cannot remain in office, which no government would do. The Bill contains a provision for an election if a government loses the confidence of the House.

We cannot avoid the question of a double dissolution, nor should we. Section 57 of the Constitution provides that if there is a disagreement between the Houses, and the Government is adamant in that disagreement, there shall be an election to decide the issue. Under this Bill that can still happen. Of course, if under this proposed legislation that should happen, the Government and some senators would hold office for only the balance of the term available. In other words, if a government were elected for three years and after two years there were a double dissolution, under this proposal the terms of the Government and of the senators first elected would expire after 12 months. The Bill contains a provision for that acceleration of events and also provides a sanction whereby the Senate would not be so anxious to be difficult if it had to face up to the fact that its terms would not be for six years but would be the life of two terms of the House of Representatives.

A memorandum has been circulated setting out what Senator Evans thinks the Government should address its mind to. He makes the point that the problems are related to the utter lack of stability and predictability in the Australian electoral cycle. We knew that. As a matter of record, we were elected in December 1972 and were under threat of not getting Supply in 1973. That was the year of our very first Budget. The supplementary Supply Bills of 1974 were also under threat, so we had to have a double dissolution. The Supply of 1974 was also under threat and, of course, the Supply of 1975 was not even conceded. We recall the tremendous tension that prevailed.

I think you would almost smile now, Mr Deputy Speaker, if you looked at the proposals of the then Senate which said that it could not give that Government life in political terms because of the rising unemployment at that time. When we consider that more than 560,000 people are unemployed now, we wonder whether the Senate might send the present Government out to the people on that basis. That was the pretext that was used on the previous occasions. Another was the dreadful inflation and yet another the suggestion that the deficit was getting a little out of hand. We are now looking at a deficit of $4 billion. We understand that government has to face the people but it should not be at the whim and the cavalier suggestion of a Senate with resolutions which have no bona fides at all . We still smile at those senators and former senators who said that they were judging us on our merits. We know that they participated in the party room discussion at which they were told: 'See whether you can get rid of that Government as soon as possible'. We know that they voted in accordance with political dictates. The concept of this legislation is to try to overcome this sort of cynicism.

I make another point. Why was an early election held in 1977? It was simply because the Australian Labor Party was likely to change its leader and the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) thought that it was so much easier to beat the leader we had in 1975 if he was still the leader in 1977. We should have gone through until 1978. But that was the real rationale. Speeches that were made in Queensland at the time readily identified that rationale. It has brought about a cynicism as to what we are all about in this place. The people are sick and tired of the number of elections. They just cannot understand how we can be making any progress by continually having elections, particularly in the present economic climate. They are looking for some national concepts. This is where Australia is so bereft at present. It has no national spirit; it is governed, or over-governed, by at least eight governments at present. The people are out of their minds and fed up to the neck because what we would call 'some administration' is costing the earth. They say that they are dreadfully over- governed, and they are right. We can never get them from this position to that of looking at a new constitution, which I think they would fairly draft on a non -political basis, with the following concept: 'We will elect the governments and they will remain for the period we determine'. As a matter of interest, I think public opinion would now be that a four-year term is better than a three-year term.

We want to have a Senate. Everybody agrees that we should have a Senate as a House of legitimate review, not a House of confrontation or a House of rejection , which it has become. If we adopted a new method of electing members of the Senate, namely, on a first-past-the-post basis rather than on the basis of proportional representation, we might get more political stability in this area; but we certainly would not get the genuine House of review or the genuine contribution that minority groups are entitled to have, which proportional representation guarantees. We need to wake up and be alert to the fact that we have a precious element called democracy. We can lose it if we go through the political mechanisms of the sheer, abrupt use of power or ambush in a Senate which is anxious always to send the House of Representatives back to the people but which would not dare to go to the people itself. That is still the unfortunate position in which we find ourselves. An effort was made in the original draft of this Bill to provide that, in terms of Supply, section 53 would not give the Senate the power which it now has to reject or not grant supply. We should bear in mind that in that context the word 'reject' does not appear in section 53. It appeared in the original draft of the Constitution and was deleted because the forefathers, in their wisdom, said that we cannot have two financial Houses, and that finance-in other words, tax-has to come from the House of the people. That was a legitimate and valid proposition. But because it did not say that the Senate shall not reject Supply, which it could have done because it assumed that by removal of the word 'reject' the Senate would not threaten Supply, during the period 1972-75 we had to face the fact that Supply was threatened and in fact not granted.

Whilst this Bill set out to say that the Senate would not do that, the Senate would not let that provision remain in the Bill, and it has been deleted from it . So we still run the dreadful gauntlet of a hostile Senate not giving a government supply and may face continual elections, a situation which this Bill cannot correct. This matter has been discussed by various constitutional conventions. The great problem with those conventions, as I said, is that they are always attended by members of parliament, both Federal and State. Naturally, those people will fight to hold their present preserve. The people of Australia do not have any input at all. It was interesting at the Perth convention to note that we in the Labor Party were asking why we need to give the Senate the power to reject Supply. Democracy is destroyed if the Senate can continually reject Supply for a government which basically needs Supply every six months. The unfortunate situation could develop in which a government could continually be returned to the people and re-elected and the Senate may not do anything about it. That would be a nonsensical situation.

We proposed suggesting to the people of Australia, on a non-party basis, that the Senate not have those ridiculous powers. Sir Charles Court put a somewhat doubtful amendment. He said that if that were to happen there ought to be a double dissolution and that it would be a sanction on the Senate. Of course, a re-election might still give the same result because the method of election is different. Proportional representation allows for minorities in the Senate. It does not allow for that anywhere else. We could well find that the Senate would still be just as difficult and the nation would become ungovernable. If we were not to give finance to a government in the normal way it would not be able to govern.

Section 53 of the Constitution-I am speaking from memory-refers to the ordinary annual services of government. It does not refer to anything special; just annual services. It refers to the continuity of government. Why should a Senate be allowed to adopt the past practice of using all sorts of mechanisms to suggest that because the economy was not going right, because inflation and unemployment were too high, a government should not get the ordinary annual appropriation? That would mean that public servants could not be paid, no money could go to the States, every school would have to close, and hospitals could not function. In other words we would have anarchy. But that was the rationale at the time. The Court amendment was no solution because no State government would be able to function if this sort of position were deemed to be the way to play the political game in Australia. If upper houses, wherever they exist, have the power to refuse Supply we will get these problems.

This nation is bedevilled enough at present. I suggest, purely on the basis of sheer intelligence in support of the principle of democracy, that we ought to have some clear indication of that what we are about in this nation is protecting people's rights. When people exercise their right to elect a government we should not destroy it on the basis that perhaps they have changed their minds in the interim. It is difficult for a government always to maintain popularity during its term if it has to introduce taxation measures. The political climate can change within three years. If the Senate is always to seize on the fact that the gallup polls show that this is the right time to remove the government we will find that it will never get Supply. The government might be anxious to impose some additional tax which the Senate, out of sheer devilment, decides not to give it at that time and wants to see whether that government can win an election now because it might not be so popular.
Generally speaking the drafting satisfies the substantial point raised about the treatment of Australian Government Employment as an industry for purposes of the Act.

The letter goes on, nevertheless to express some reservations about the amendment. My Department has replied to that letter. The gist of the reply is that we can see no reason to depart from what is in the amendment now proposed. I have shown the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) the latest correspondence, just as he has seen the earlier letters between the ACOA and me. I therefore commend the amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief in regard to this matter. I think that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) has accurately put the matter. The unions raised a legitimate point regarding their capacity to organise in the industry identified. It is to the credit of the Minister and his Department that they have responded with alacrity and positively to the real problem that was raised by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Associations. It is also correct, as the Minister indicated, that he has been good enough to show me the correspondence between him and Mr Munro of the ACOA. I understand, through not having received any further communication from the ACOA or the Australian Council of Trade Unions, that they have concluded that the action taken by the Government in bringing this amendmend before us meets the subtance of the point the Opposition, as with the main Bill, the Conciliation and Arbitration (Complementary Industrial Relations System) Amendment Bill I express no opposition to the amendments which the Minister has brought before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Macphee)-by leave-read a third time.

All those judgments by the Senate would be political judgments. They would not be based on fairness, equity or democracy but on the continual struggle for power and supremacy. The fixed term parliament proposals give us some indirect solution. It is not the best solution. Senator Evans admits that. He said that the legislation is the second best solution. It does not involve talking about the past, the errors or the mistakes. It is trying to offer some reasonable alternative. We still face the overwhelming problem that the power of Supply can be destructively exercised. But the real issue is that the basic constitutional prohibition of premature elections would make the blocking of Supply perhaps pointless and politically counter-productive. To the extent that the basic prohibition could be avoided in a particular case-for example, by the existence at the time of the blocking of some deadlocked measure for which the double dissolution trigger was already cocked-the argument is that the rule that an incoming government could only serve out the term of the predecessor would operate as an overwhelming, practical disincentive to the Senate pursuing the matter. I think that is right.

The Bill provides for a basic fixed term and it amends section 28 of the Constitution. There are further amendments to indicate clearly that the Senate terms are equivalent to two House of Representatives terms. The conditions are created for Senate elections to be always held at the same time as House of Representatives elections. There are further amendments to the Constitution to ensure that the writs for House and Senate elections are issued at the proper time. I make the point that one could have the House of Representatives passing a no confidence motion. If that happened there would have to be an election for the House of Representatives but it would be only for the balance of the term.

One can think of situations which perhaps show gaps in this Bill on which we need not dwell because we are basically talking about the positive aspects. One could find extraordinary situations in which one might not have a Prime Minister or the Prime Minister resigns and, therefore, no advice could be given to a Governor-General. But those possibilities are so remote in practical terms that we had better not waste too much time on them. The point we are anxious to make is that there will always be opportunities to remove bad governments. The best way to do it is through the people in the normal course and not by a Senate trying to judge its views. Certainly, if there were a motion of no confidence in the House it would not mean that one has to go to an election if, in fact, one could reform a government within the context of the occupants of the House of Representatives. If they could get a vote of confidence there would be no need for the unnecessary election. I think that all Senator Evans is saying in these expressions is that he has a chance to indicate clearly that we might go along the track to solving the difficulties we have experienced.

As he has said, this Bill is a serious minded and realistic attempt to grapple with the questions of fundamental constitutional importance and of crucial importance to the future of our parliamentary system. It is a genuine attempt to find a possible middle-of-the-road solution, as Senator Evans calls it, to the major problems which have been weighing heavily on both sides. We want to ensure , in the interests of the Australian people, that democracy really means something and that it can work. We should leave it to the people to judge the question of when governments should be changed and not to the Senate. The subject matter, as Senator Evans says, is such that the temptation to score in political terms is obvious. But it is a temptation which has been resisted in the course of this debate. The only way constitutional reform on this or any other issue can be achieved is through consensus. I think that is clear.

If we can get the Australian nation to reach consensus-which I think can be done-on a new Constitution we will make enormous progress in this country. People would identify with the concept of one nation, one Australia. They do this in times of crisis. Unfortunately, the crises are usually wars. A better Australian spirit was never seen than when Australia was under attack and its very survival was at stake. Nobody worried what State he belonged to or where he was born; it was a question of Australia surviving. Our present world has shrunk but is very competitive. Distances are no guarantee of safety. There is competition for survival in other nations and in our own. If we are not able to make a go of democracy and a success of this nation, if we are too divided on the major issues, other nations will look at that as weakness. They are entitled to do so. Many of them, of course, do not practice democracy and are not likely to do so. We do not want democracy to be second best simply because words can be manipulated.

If we look at the intentions of the people who drafted the Constitution we find that they were anxious to create a strong and fair Australia in which all people had equal rights. A proper constitution is desperately needed. Knowing the conservative nature of the Government, we think that this is something that the Government might be prepared to offer the people. The only way it can do that is to pass the Bill we are now introducing. The Opposition makes the point that an opposition certainly ought to be able to bring down a government, but should only be able to do it in the House of Representatives. That is clearly the position. I make the point again that we are no longer urging the abolition of the Senate. We think it has a valuable role to play; one of an intelligent contribution towards legislation, not one of playing the gut politics of going for the jugular vein to prevent the lifeblood of Supply.
Sir James Killen-I should know but I don't; do I take it that your Party no longer advocates the abolition of the Senate?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr LIONEL BOWEN

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not. It has altered its platform.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sir James Killen-Senator Evans, when he arrived, in his maiden speech--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr LIONEL BOWEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know Senator Evans was in the chamber. I am delighted to see him. I hope he does not mind my saying this, but I think our party policy also suggests that we should not have any Ministers in the Senate. The Leader of the House would not object to that. With the Evans Bill, as we call it-I think it is entitled to have that profile because he deserves a lot of praise for the effort that has gone into it and enormous praise for even getting it through the Senate, which shows that there is some hope at times-the issue there is--

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Ruddock-A free vote?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr LIONEL BOWEN

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, a free vote, if that will help at all. I mentioned other restraints. I will not weary the House with them. The Bill is positive in what it offers. It offers, as Senator Evans said, not the best but the second best solution. It is a good solution if in the use of the second best we can get the best, by what would be called custom or convention, in that the Senate will not continue to urge elections as it wants as opposed to what the people need. There could be no better time to discuss this matter than in the present world economic climate. It is not very healthy. The world is re-arming and is very anxious about energy resources. It is certainly going to need them. If we talk to the scientists of the world we find the world will be very short indeed of a number of necessary resources which Australia has. If Australia does not make a proper contribution to the stability of democracy it is endangering its very lifeblood. It is also perhaps guaranteeing that somebody else will take a very keen interest.

INTERJECT.PARA: The political representation Australians have is not the best. It is not A- grade material; it is very much lower than C-grade. When one looks at the politics that have been played in the past one sees that it has been in what one would call the kindergarten or infantile stage. It has offered nothing by way of a solution to what we are about. The Evans Bill has done something. It has altered the people of Australia-those who think and want to discuss on a non- party calm basis what ought to be done-to the fact that we need something done about this Constitution. A small and a very valuable step is to guarantee that the House of Representatives can have a fixed term. I commend the Bill to the House.
