DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF FORT QUEENSCLIFF, QUEENSCLIFF, VICTORIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of Fort Queenscliff, Queenscliff, Victoria.

The proposal is for the provision of new and upgraded facilities at the Army Command and Staff College, Queenscliff. In recommending construction of the work in the reference the Committee concluded that existing facilities are inadequate for the present and future requirements of the staff college and recommended their replacement. The Committee concluded also that the scope and design of the proposed redevelopment is justified. The estimated cost of the work is $8.3m in September 1982 prices. The Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion for new works at Queenscliff. In the last couple of weeks the fort at Queensliff has been subject to centenary celebations. In recent times a great deal of restoration work has taken place there. It is a very important asset, I believe, in our historical annals. It is well worth preserving. Those people who have done work in that area of preservation-largely private work, nevertheless with considerable support-have done an extremely good job in restoring or maintaining one of our assets.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other side of Port Phillip Bay-as the by-election is over I can say this without anyone suggesting this is political-the Officer Cadet School at Portsea is to move, in the not too distant future, its operations to Duntroon because of the building of the Australian Defence Force Academy and the surplus capacity which will then come about. That area, for very different purposes, should also be the subject of very serious discussion-I know that the matter is under active consideration-as to the permanency of occupation of the Commonwealth in that area. On both sides of the bay there are historic military reasons why we should be there. There are good environmental reasons why the area on the Portsea side of the bay should not be allowed to be over-utilised or damaged.

I raise that matter because it is one of those that may get lost by change, cost cutting or some other factor in the not too distant future. If the area is ever subject to relaxed vigilance it will, in fact, disappear. This will include , very likely, substantial proportions of the coastline. That will change the whole environment of Port Phillip Bay and the surrounding areas. It is very welcome that the works at Queenscliff are to be commenced and completed. Fort Queenscliff is a very important part of our current military training. The senior Army staff college operates at Queenscliff. That area is not represented by me at the moment; it was when I was first elected. I welcome the works that are to be done. I congratulate those who in the very recent past have done an enormous job of restoration in that area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Mr N.A. Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1982 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1982, as they are related measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a cognate debate for the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982 and two consequential measures, the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1982 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1982. We applaud the legislation so far as it goes but we do not think it really goes far enough. The policy of the Australian Labor Party is to get new services into regions and, as far as it can, encourage local inputs without going too far in the direction of parochialism. We are concerned that the local organisations, stations and outlets should not be swamped by networks. It is also important that stations have a fair prospect of viability.

SPEECH.PARA: The intention of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill is to get such services into the country. Although the Opposition will not oppose the second reading of the Bill, it thinks that the legislation proposed is incomplete. We would like to have seen a broader consideration of the broadcasting system as a whole. We take the view that, if new services cannot be obtained by the existing commercial configuration, perhaps there ought to be more opportunity for public or national broadcasting. It is long overdue for the Government to consider what it will do about a second Australian Broadcasting Commission regional network, for example, and to provide further outlets for community stations especially in those areas, some of them metropolitan areas, which are not presently serviced such as Melbourne's western suburbs about which I have spoken to the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown) on several occasions. The Bill introduces supplementary licences for television and amends existing provisions so far unused for radio. It increases the maximum size of the membership of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal from five to eight.

There is a different concept in this Bill from its parent Act. There is the provision for the licensing of services rather than the licensing of transmitters. In this legislation, a supplementary licence is one granted in the same area to an existing licensee. It is not subject to the normal ownership and control provisions, that is, it is seen as being one with the existing licence for certain purposes. The legislation does not apply to the five mainland State capitals. The question of supplementary licences does not arise for them. Under the legislation for radio, the supplementaries must be by frequency modulation transmission. For television ultra high frequency or very high frequency and radiated subscription services are permitted. Under the legislation, a total of 99 commercial FM services and 36 commercial TV services could be established.

As I said earlier, the Bill creates licences for services as distinct from the existing system of licences for transmitters. If a service area requires several transmitters-that is, the main one and one or more translaters-one licence is to cover the lot. The procedure is this: An existing licensee applies to the Minister for a single supplementary licence. A consortium of licensees serving the same area may also apply. The Minister may accept the application and forward it to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which may conduct an inquiry into the grant. Secondly, the Minister may reject it on planning or technical grounds. In response the Broadcasting Tribunal will either recommend to the Minister that invitations for an independent licence be issued or grant the supplementary licence for up to a five-year period. It should be noted that the position with respect to a potential independent who may initiate action for a licence is unaffected by the Bill. However, it could be affected by the establishment of a government policy on supplementary manifest by the Bill. At the moment if a person-that is, a natural person or a legal entity-wants a licence in an area he fills in an expression of interest form with the Department, which then asks him to complete a planning pro forma. The pro forma must then pass the test of whether it is within government policy. If it is, the Minister at that point makes a decision on whether he will invite an application . This existing procedure is unaffected by the Bill.

Until now, with no settled policy on how commercial frequency modulation services are to be extended to the country, no application has passed the test of whether it is within government policy. Now that a policy has been settled it is theoretically possible for the Minister to invite applications. However, it seems likely that the Minister will never invite an application for an independent licence as a result of this process because to do so would be to declare that a particular independent is viable-something that otherwise would normally be a matter for determination by the Tribunal. A Minister would be in a somewhat embarrassing situation if, after holding an inquiry, the Broadcasting Tribunal knocked him back and cast doubt on his judgment because it did not think the application had viability. So presumably it is a right that would be exercised with some trepidation by a Minister-unless perhaps it was the Minister 's predecessor.

Although there is nothing about it in the Bill, it is understood that when the Minister makes a statement on the scheme after the Bill's passage he will announce the date by which applications must be in from existing licensees. Otherwise he will say that he will call for independent licensees to make their applications. But this is considered a hollow threat. The reality of the situation is that all licensees will apply to forestall independence. There will be a long queue for processing. I do not know whether the mills of the ABT grind exceedingly small but they certainly grind very slowly. The fact that it is chronically short of staff and there are many-

TALK.START.PARA: —Efficient government.

—Not when it does not deliver the goods. That is the test of efficiency. In holding its inquiry the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is required to determine whether an independent commercial licence would be viable and, if so, whether it would be in the public interest to invite applications. There is simply no specification of what the onus of proof of viability is and where it lies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill says that the Broadcasting Tribunal is to have regard only to the following public interest criteria: Firstly, the nature of the community to be served; secondly, the diversity of the interests of the community; and, thirdly, the nature of the broadcasting and television services of which satisfactory reception is being obtained by the community. Honourable members should note that there is no reference to any criteria such as media concentration of Press and other electronic media holdings because of that word 'only'. The ABT cannot take them into account. Honourable members should note also that there are no public interest criteria whatsoever for the granting of a supplementary licence. In other words, an existing licensee can argue against an independent applicant on two broad grounds-that is to say, non-viability and that the public interest criteria are not satisfied. By contrast, a potential independent applicant cannot argue against a supplementary licence on public interest grounds, presumably because the Bill specifies grounds to be noted for an independent applicant but not for a supplementary licence that precludes general grounds or grounds arising elsewhere in the Act in considering a supplementary licence. It therefore seems that potential independents will not be treated equally with the incumbents. It is not known what the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal criteria of viability will be but presumably consistent criteria would have to be developed.

After eight years of operation, special renewal procedures take effect. At that stage the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal must determine whether an independent licence would be viable and, if so, whether it would be in the public interest to invite applications. If the ABT determines that an independent licence is viable, it then renews the supplementary licence for up to two years and recommends the Minister to invite applications for an independent service to begin three years later. There is then a procedure whereby the licensee can give up one of his two licences and transfer it; that is, he can sell it and only if he cannot sell it does a hearing take place for the independents. The effect of this, of course, is that the licensee is in a position where he selects his successor and gets the market value of the station.

On the face of it, if the licensee has scope under the ownership and control of provisions-that is, if he has not got a prescribed interest in the permitted maximum number of licences-he could transfer the licence to a company controlled by himself. He would then be in a position to own two independent licences in the one area. However, by virtue of clause 2 of the Bill, existing section 89A ( 1D) (c) (ii) of the act will apply to the transfer of a supplementary licence. This provides that the Broadcasting Tribunal shall have regard to 'the need to avoid undue concentration of influence' on the transferee, where a country licence is being transferred. This could presumably allow the Broadcasting Tribunal to refuse consent to a transfer even within the ownership and control limits. It should be noted that the Government has deliberately made a point of trying to prevent undue concentration in this case. Therefore, it may be argued that it admits the principle and it should be applied to the granting of supplementary licences in some way.

The approach adopted by the Opposition is: Firstly, we agree that a principle should be adopted and that some way has to be found for country areas to get new services; secondly, we believe that new services should, if possible, be independent of existing ones to provide for a greater range of choice; thirdly, we agree that if independent services could not possibly be viable, then supplementary licences should be issued; and, fourthly, we insist on avoiding undue concentration of influence across all media, which we believe is not only in the public interest but also even in the interests of advertisers. Therefore, we will propose some amendments giving guidence to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal; for example, by directing it to adopt a liberal attitude to the question of viability.

If, for instance, a station which is automated is doing, say, the 'beautiful music' format which is common on some frequency modulation stations using syndicated news services it may well be that it could be profitable on a much lower budget than is conventionally regarded as necessary in the industry. There is very little in the way of overheads and hardly anything in labour costs. If one station in the area is local, there is also the possibility that program regulations could be adjusted to relax localism requirements for an FM commercial station. There is also the philosophical point about the degree to which governments should guarantee a market in such an industry. At the moment that is the Government's problem. The fact is that neither the Department nor the Broadcasting Tribunal has the resources, nor I think the critical attitude necessary to develop and to establish an appropriate viability level. Both will be heavily influenced by the existing industry in whose interests it will be to set the level as high as possible. The only real way to tell would be to let some independent operators try it out and then observe the results.

At the Committee stage I will move an amendment to ensure that a potential independent has the same facility to initiate an inquiry as an incumbent; secondly, an amendment to create a presumption of viability of an independent; and, thirdly, an amendment requiring the Broadcasting Tribunal to have regard to concentration of influence in granting a supplementary licence. Obviously the very act of granting a supplementary licence may be in itself-that is a supplementary licence to an already existing licencee-a concentrating of service . So the test would not apply to that. The granting is regarded as a last resort if there is no possibility of independent viability being established. But there remains the problem of concentration across other media. It is not a theoretical problem. In Tasmania, for instance, the Rouse interests own all television stations, Launceston and Hobart radio and the Press. As the Bill stands there is nothing preventing them gaining an extra television station and an extra radio station in both Launceston and Hobart. That would surely, even to this libertarian Government, be excessive.

The Department's rationale is to say: 'But if one denies them supplementaries on the ground of concentration then you deny the people of Tasmania, or wherever , services. Therefore you have to give it to the existing interests. It is too bad but there it is'. This argument stands up only if there is no other way in which these commercial services can be provided. There are at least two other recourses and the procedure would go like this: Firstly, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would look at viability and then apply a public interest test on concentration, taking regard to media concentration generally, factors of ownership and also general geographical factors. If a case fails the concentration test-that is, where there is undue concentration such as in the Rouse case-then clearly the viability test could be more liberal insofar as it affects the incumbent. In other words, in business terms, because the incumbent owns radio, Press and television he would be less seriously affected by a forced sharing of, for example, the radio market with a newspaper, with a newcomer, than if he were simply a radio operator and nothing else because he is able to spread his general business risk. Different viability criteria apply. His own viability would not be seriously threatened if he had a competitor in the field. Thus we could argue that the viability test be removed altogether in that case or in the general case of an incumbent who has extensive support elsewhere in the media. For example, take the case of Rupert Murdoch. Or at least there could be a heavy onus on the incumbent to prove why a newcomer would actually damage the services to the area, quite apart from the question of whether he would damage his own profits. In other words, it would be on the newcomer's head to make a go of it.

Secondly, alternatively as a competitive proposition to be put to the Tribunal, there could be aggregation of service areas for purposes of providing independent services where single service areas are found to be non-viable but where the incumbent fails the concentration test. In general there must be economies in running a networking situation over several service areas. Therefore there must be an aggregation of service areas so that the aggregation is viable. Although a lack of localism may be advanced as an argument against this there are undoubtedly areas which have very strong regional features such as the Central West and North Coast of New South Wales or Gippsland. Each area encompasses several local service areas and they are identifiably regions in economic and other terms, such as sport. There is of course, a long-standing case for the promotion of regional radio and television.

The third factor is that although more politically difficult it would be possible to permit the granting of a supplementary licence to an incumbent radio or television station only if that licence were divested from any concentrated pan-media grouping. Such a provision would need to be accompanied by a way of ensuring that a potential independent could initiate an inquiry. But if there was no right to initiate an inquiry the incumbent would just sit tight. There could be a provision saying that if the incumbent refused to divest, as he would of course, then an independent would be allowed to proceed with his application as a matter of course. While admitting that here would be areas where the only recourse would be supplementary licences, it is highly likely that the existing industry greatly overstates the viability issue because it is in its obvious direct interest to do so. Furthermore, given eight years of incumbency it is highly unlikely that a station would ever be divested. The industry would prevail on a Liberal-National Party Government, if such a government were in office, to change the Act if that ever looked like happening. There are plenty of precedents for that.

As I mentioned earlier in my opening remarks, the other two pieces of legislation are merely consequential. The Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill and the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill simply provide for the licencees to be paid for supplementary licences. In conclusion I point out to the House that at the Committee stage we will be raising a number of matters by way of amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Broadcasting Television Amendment Bill, in terms of listeners to radio stations and viewers of television stations in country areas of Australia, is probably one of the most significant pieces of legislation to come before this Parliament in more than 20 years. It is part of the overall long term Government project of extending to those people in remote and rural areas the best available programming that can be provided through existing television and radio services. This is yet another step by this Government to try to bring to them that range of services which obviously in the past they have so sorely missed. In fact, it is an opportunity for some 99 commercial FM radio services and 36 new television services to be considered for these rural and remote areas of Australia. That in itself is rather a significant move. I do not really think that any honourable member in this House would deny that the choice of programs available to many of these rural listeners and viewers has in the past been most restricted indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other interesting aspects of this Bill is the fact that it is directed, in the case of radio, primarily to the FM mode. That is important too. I suppose in many respects it was almost by mistake that Australia was introduced to FM radio which potentially is the best broadcasting medium that we can possibly provide in this country. If we take our minds back through history we will see that under the terms of the old Wireless Telegraphy Act FM radio was initially introduced into Australia. This legislation helps in providing a more professional use of FM radio and, most importantly, a professional use of FM radio in these regional and remote areas of Australia. It is an opportunity for existing country stations to test the markets and to see whether they can provide alternative programming through this particular mode.

I was interested to listen tonight to the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) and some of his arguments that he put. Honourable members will excuse me I am sure if I am wrong in saying that I think there was almost an assumption in his speech that most of the existing country radio operators were almost sitting on a bed of roses in terms of their profitability. I do not really think that is the case. In actual fact an analysis of the incomes and profit margins of many regional operators in Australia would show that their viability is very much at stake. I would also see this legislation as providing them with an opportunity to try to make their present situation more viable for very little outlay. Certainly there are opportunities within the proposed legislation for a market to be tested to see whether so many of these regional centres may in their own right be entitled to an additional independent service. Importantly too I think we have to give that opportunity to back up many of these regional operators so they can continue to provide not only their AM service but also these alternative services as well. Of course, one would hope that they would take great advantage of their opportunity to enter this particular mode-the FM mode- especially to provide all that is best in terms of the technical quality in the broadcasting services. That really is what FM radio is all about. One would hope that any operator of these particular licences would move to use that medium to the very best advantage.

With the capital city stations-certainly this legislation does not apply to them-we have seen a very great acceptance of FM by listeners. A look at recent radio services around Australia would certainly indicate that the general public is adapting to such stations very quickly indeed. Surveys would indicate a very great increase in the number of listeners to FM radio services in capital cities . That has especially been so in cities such as Perth-as shown in recent surveys -and Brisbane and Sydney as well. We could see that as indicating that perhaps Australians are quicker than most people in other countries to adapt to new forms of communications and to new services that might be available. In that respect, the legislation should be welcome. It is a very real opportunity for Australians to have even greater diversity in their radio information and entertainment.

I mentioned a little earlier that this is just part of a total package of this Government to expand the whole area of communications on a much grander scale than we have known in the past. It provides an opportunity for Australians in country and remote areas to receive full services and an opportunity for people in the cities over the next few years to have on their hands almost a revolution in communications. Whilst we speak tonight of the supplementary licences for FM radio and for rural television interests, it is only a few years down the track when Australia will be benefiting from the services that the communication satellite can bring and from the even more exciting prospects of the introduction of radiated subscription television or cable television.

Although the legislation before the House tonight will not give the electronics industry such a tremendous chance to increase its participation in the manufacturing areas of the industry, I guess that it is a start. The Australian industry has caught on to FM radio, and one wonders what the true potential of the whole area of communications will be over the next five years. At a time when we are looking for employment and when the Australian electronics industry is going through severe periods of hardship, legislation such as this can in itself create a lot of the much needed employment in Australia. One hopes that this Government will be forward-looking enough in its very near future to make some very real statements about the future of the new communications media, especially cable television. We have already had in this House over the last few years some debates about the communications capabilities of cable television. One would think it was almost time for the Government to start really making some recommendations about the possible introduction of cable television, perhaps even more than RSTV, for the future expansion of the electronics industry in Australia.

I would be most happy if the Government would make a commitment for the almost immediate introduction of cable television services in Australia. I say that bearing in mind that we have to make some rather hard decisions about the regulations that might govern the future of cable television in Australia. If we look at the cold, hard facts, we see that Australians have proved themselves to be amongst world leaders in accepting new technology. That was evident with the introduction of colour television into Australia. Within a matter of months of the introduction of colour television, something like 62 per cent of homes in this country were saturated with it. Australia has the greatest acceptance of any country in the world of home videotape recorders. The saturation level is something like 32 per cent already. With the early introduction of cable television services, which would cover not only entertainment but also all sorts of information services, that record would be improved upon even more.

The most exciting part of the introduction of cable television is not the services that it can bring but the employment opportunities that it can provide at a time such as this. On my estimations even the announcement of the initial plans to go ahead with cable television could start in the employment area such a revolution that, by the time it was introduced, at least 20,000 jobs would have been created in the electronics industry. The introduction of cable television here would mean a very high usage of labour. It would mean also a very high usage of capital, and at a time such as this that is probably what we need more than anything else. There is no denying that cable television would be restricted initially to the capital cities only. But that is well and good because that is where it will be viable and easily introduced and that is where there is already an expectation of the new technology which is just around the corner. If we introduce 20,000 jobs into the electronics industry, we can also look at the entertainment and information aspects of cable to see what sort of employment they will generate too.

The experience in the United States of America is that cable television services are great consumers of television programs of all types, not only in the entertainment area but also in the information area. Already a fledgling industry in Australia is providing some entertainment services to cable television stations in the United States. I am sure that most members of this House have already heard of the acceptance, for example, of Australian Rules football in the Los Angeles area. I guess it was a case of providing some fill- in programs but it certainly opened a whole new market for the Australian football business on the West Coast of the United States. A gentleman I know from my home city of Brisbane who has been producing a travel series for Australian television services has just sold his programs to an American cable concern. His return on the cost of that production has been about three times his outlay. Already he is making plans for the expansion of that service throughout other areas of the United States. I suppose that is an indication of the potential for Australia if we get into that mode early enough.

There is an opportunity in the general information areas and the educational areas for Australians to take advantage of this whole new technology. If we can get in early enough we can provide not only a home market but also a whole new export market. I hope that within the coming months we will look very seriously indeed at getting down to the job and making sure that we have our own regulations correct in terms of the things that should govern the introduction of cable television. I hope that Australia will get on the bandwagon and take advantage not only of the local market but also, through our own technology and the advancements that have already been made in that field, an export market of not inconsiderable proportions through Asia and beyond in the years to come.

As I said at the beginning of my address tonight, this legislation is yet another step in the ever-expanding concern that this Government has for all Australians to receive the best communications services available. This will certainly mean that people in many of the country areas of Australia will have a greater diversity of services and a greater quality of services. In those respects, with the safeguards that are envisaged in this legislation, I certainly commend the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) made most of the main points that need to be made by the Opposition in relation to this legislation. I will confine my remarks to certain aspects which I think are important and which illustrate the reasons for our amendments. To begin with , I think there has been a slight misrepresentation of the importance of this legislation. An extremely important measure is being undertaken here. A series of improved radio and television services is proposed not just for what might be called the strictly country areas but also for large regional cities. In fact, the provisions of the legislation extend to every place in Australia except the five capital cities. They extend not only to remote areas but also to major cities, such as Newcastle, Wollongong, Hobart, Launceston, Darwin and Alice Springs. In that sense the provisions before us deal not just with inadequate services in certain remote areas but also with cities of hundreds of thousands of people. In that sense they have to be looked at carefully, not simply in terms of the claimed aims but also in terms of what they are going to do in relation to the concentration of media ownership in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Australian Labor Party applaud any attempt to increase services for country areas. We believe that there should be a maximum effort on the part of the Government to provide such increased radio and television services. It should be emphasised that this legislation is not concerned with the different methods of providing such regional services but is primarily concerned with the provision of commercial services. In my view the commercial nature of these services needs to be questioned. Let us ask this question: If we are concerned to provide more regional and country services why are we not giving out more public radio licences and extending Australian Broadcasting Corporation services and multicultural and ethnic services? This legislation does not address itself to those areas at all. It does not address itself to the matter of more public radio or television. There is a big demand for the extension of public radio and television in these other regional centres. As I mentioned, they are not all remote centres; some of them are very big cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can already get a licence under the Wireless Telegraphy Act.
—Not under the provisions of this legislation. They can apply only if they are prepared to take on advertising and what have you.
—What is wrong with that?

—What I am saying is that this legislation deals primarily with commercial interests and not with the other aspects of the problem. The Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown) has explained why it is that the Government, if it is sincere in wanting to provide these extra services, has not put forward a program of extending public radio and television or extending the ABC. In many places throughout Australia the ABC has only one radio station rather than two. Certainly, there is a growing need throughout the nation for consideration of second ABC television stations. The Goverment has made comments about extending multicultural television to other areas but it has not gone beyond the capital cities. It has not mentioned these other regional centres. In many of these regional centres there are substantial concentrations of ethnic people, and they need to be taken into account. Ethnic radio has been a great success in the capital cities, but again there has been no provision of ethnic radio for regional and country centres where, as I mentioned, people who speak other languages and for whom English is a second language do not have anything like the same opportunities as people in the capital cities.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that needs to be emphasised-in fact it comes up in relation to considerations of ethnic radio-is the Government's commercial interest and its perpetual concern with profit rather than the provision of services. This matter has come out even in the area of ethnic radio. A report which has recently been prepared argues that the ethnic radio stations, 2EA and 3EA, ought to be given over to private enterprise and made commercial radio stations. This would be an extremely retrograde step which would be totally resisted by all ethnic communities. In fact what we ought to be doing is considering extending these kinds of services that are provided by 2EA and 3EA to regional centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no people of ethnic origin there anyway.

—That is typical of your knowledge. If the honourable member refers to regional cities such as Newcastle and says that there are no people of ethnic origin in those places that goes to show how much he knows about Australia. Let me now express what our difficulties are in relation to the commercial stations. First, the provisions in the Bill are such that they discourage the establishment of independent licences. The independent licensee has to prove that his proposition is commercially viable. If he has to prove that, those who are interested in a supplementary licence can make submissions to try to disprove his claim. In other words, those who may have a vested interest in getting hold of a supplementary licence in fact will be trying to discourage the Government from granting a licence to an independent. This is a serious matter. We know from experience that this is the sort of tactic Australia's media monopolies carry out.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House once again that we are not talking only about small towns; we are talking about large cities being involved in this situation. We are talking about multimillion dollar operations and the profits which can be made from gaining access to radio and television licences in these cities. In that context, the fact that those who are applying for supplementary licences will be given preference in a certain way to those applying for independent licences under the provisions of this Bill-this was outlined by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones)-indicates the extent to which, in fact, this Government is committed to the existent monopolies in broadcasting and television. Time and again we in the Labor Party have complained about the concentration of media ownership. The Bill in its present form does not prevent, for example, a huge media giant who has big interests in the capital cities from applying for a supplementary licence in a large city such as Hobart or Wollongong. Not only is he not prevented but also he can put in various claims to discredit someone who applies for an independent licence. Obviously, those sorts of people have the money, the know-how and the expertise to do this and to undermine those who would like an independent licence to be granted.

What do we see in this Bill? In the guise of a pretence of wanting to extend services-we have no quarrel with the extension of services-we see very little in the way of provision of public services, government services or ethnic services, but we see the attempt to provide a supplementary licence setup which, in fact, clearly favours those who are already in the media monopoly game and which discourages those who wish to establish independent stations. Our amendments do not oppose the extension of the services. They make this a fairer game in that those who are seeking an independent licence will be given some benefit of the doubt and also they will be able to argue against the granting of a supplementary licence in the same way in which the person who wants a supplementary licence can argue against those who are seeking the independent licence. That leads me to the final point, which concerns local content and local programs. How can a multi-media monopoly, if it gets hold of all these regional stations--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know they are going to?

—According to the provisions of this Bill they will. Do not worry about that. In the big regional centres that is what they will do. As I mentioned, some very big cities are involved under the provisions of this Bill. If those multimedia monopolies get hold of the supplementary licences, what kind of local content will be provided for the people in local areas? These monopolies do not care very much about local content. They are not concerned about providing local news services and all the rest of it. Their interest is simply to maximise their profitability. Given that situation, the aim of the Bill could very easily be undermined. The original aim of the Bill was to provide, in these regional and local centres, independent radio and television stations for the local community. If these stations are not to be independent they will not provide those sorts of things for the local community. Anyone who does not see that clear point is simply kidding himself when, as I mentioned, especially in the big regional centres, millions and millions of dollars of profits will be involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that of course in smaller regional centres where an independent station is not viable we do not oppose this supplementary principle. In my view the amendments we are putting forward will solve the kinds of difficulties which I have raised regarding the concentration of media ownership and the failure to provide for local content. I remind honourable members opposite that there is no provision in the Bill which requires that local stations actually have substantial local content at all. I believe that the Government ought to accept the amendments moved by the Opposition to ensure that we get a bipartisan approach to this matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 8-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first two amendments the Opposition offers relate to clause 8 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to sub-section (3), the holder of a licence for a commercial broadcasting station or a consortium each member of which is the holder of such a licence may lodge with the Minister, in accordance with a form approved by the Minister, an application for the grant of a licence-

And so on. We simply propose to add to new sub-sections 82A (1) and 82A (2) of the principal Act the words, 'or any other person'. The point is simply that the purpose of this amendment is to put potential independent operators on the same footing as the holders of the licences to initiate an inquiry into the grant of supplementary and independent licences. As the Bill stands, only holders may initiate an inquiry. If one is a holder of a licence, an incumbent, it is extremely unlikely one would want to have an inquiry so that one could be knocked off. It is like sitting members of the Liberal Party or indeed of any other party saying, 'Look, I think I will initiate a challenge to myself for pre -selection'. It does not make an awful lot of sense. One cannot imagine that there would be too many incumbents who would be racing around trying to organise somebody to run against them. If one is to have an inquiry, if one is to have the option open, one has to have the right of application by the person who wants to challenge the status quo.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can do that under existing legislation.

—Let us make that clear. The legislation is by no means-as the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown), I think, would generously concede- the easiest piece of legislation in the world to read. It is not exactly Gibbonian in its lucidity.
—Gibberish.

—Yes. It is quite patent on the face of proposed new section 82A that that right is exclusively the right of the licence holder. The licence holder is the only person named who may lodge an application with the Minister. If the Minister says that there is some alternative right, no doubt he will exercise his rights to explain what it is. But I think we have to make this absolutely clear by inserting the words 'or any other person' in proposed new sections 82A (1) and 82A (2). If the existing licensee does not really want a supplementary licence-of course, he may be doubtful about its economic value to him-he can block the process of determination whether there should be an independent or a supplementary licence by simply not applying. In other words, if he does not want the matter opened up at all, he just does nothing. There may be a marginal case for that, one way or the other.
—Then it lapses and others can apply for it.

—That is not at all clear in this provision. I would be interested to hear, as a piece of textual exegesis, the honourable member's views on it. We believe on the basis of our policy that a prime requirement is to get new services to rural areas. There should be a process whereby a determination can be brought to a head.

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments which may be made against an amendment to the clause are, firstly , that anyone can apply to a Minister now to invite an application. There is no formal process for this-just a request to the Minister whose power it is to call for applicants. This is true. But, since the Bill gives the right to an existing licensee to apply, it should as a matter of equity give the same right to others . Secondly, it may be argued that we are creating a new automatic right and therefore taking planning power away from the Minister. We argue that that is not so because the legislation makes a recommendation that the Minister call for applications for a licence if the Minister finds that an independent licence is viable. We could have put up an amendment making it mandatory for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to grant an independent licence. This would have made a parallel process to the granting of a supplementary licence. But we believe that the recommendation carries enough force. We think the opportunity should be there for further review by the Minister.

The Minister may argue that all licensees will apply anyway or that he will announce that he will call applications for independent licences in all areas if applications for supplementary licences are not received by a certain date. There is no reason why a potential independent should be held up by such a process or be made subject to the Minister's discretion when that independent's competitors-the existing licensees-have a statutory right. It is just a matter of simple equity. The incumbent has a statutory right conferred by the legislation; in effect, the independent is subject to the discretion of the Minister. He relies on ministerial whim, if one likes. We believe that that is quite inequitable. Therefore, I urge the Government to accept the amendments to insert in both cases the words 'or any other person'. I seek leave to move the two amendments together.
Leave granted.
I move:
(1) Clause 8, page 4, line 6, after 'licence' insert 'or any other person'.
(2) Clause 8, page 4, line 14, after 'licence' insert 'or any other person'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that at 10 o'clock the procedures of the chamber will take effect, but in the meantime, I say that the Government is not able to accept the two amendments that the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) has moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I shall report progress.

INTERJECT.PARA: Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr N.A. Brown-I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said a moment ago that the Government was not able to accept the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). The reason why the Government is not able to accept those amendments is that they proceed, with the greatest of respect, upon a misapprehension of the nature of the supplementary licence scheme. The very basis of the supplementary licence scheme is that machinery is created by the Bill under which the licensee is able to activate the whole mechanism. He is able, as the Bill provides, to lodge with the Minister an application for the grant, in effect, of a supplementary licence. To say that somebody other than the holder of the licence can do that is, with the greatest of respect, a nonsense. It would be the exact complete negation of the whole supplementary licence scheme to provide, as the honourable member for Lalor has proposed, that someone other than the current licensee has the right to lodge the application. Even if one accepted the sort of principle that the honourable member has contended should be implemented, he would have to do a complete redrafting exercise of the present provision. That is so because the honourable member for Lalor would ask us to accept that when his amendment was added to the Bill, proposed new section 82A for example, would mean that the holder of the licence for a commercial broadcasting station, et cetera, may lodge with the Minister, et cetera, an application for the grant of a licence for a broadcasting service to someone other than himself. Clearly, the other person would not be applying for a supplementary licence. As I said, the proposed amendments are not consistent with the whole structure of the scheme. If one wanted to implement the principle contended for it would require the whole series of provisions to be redrafted.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, I make the point that the proposed amendments would have the effect of compressing two inquiries into one and telescoping two independent inquiry processes involved in the supplementary licence scheme into one public inquiry. That would mean that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would be required to decide two things at the one time and in the one hearing. In the first place it would have to decide whether an independent licence was viable and in the public interest and whether a supplementary licence should be issued to an existing licensee. It would also have to determine, if an independent licence were viable, which of the applicants should be offered the licence. I do not know whether anyone would be able to work out who was bouncing the ball at an inquiry of that sort but it would be, in our submission, unnecessarily confusing if the Tribunal were embarking upon a joint inquiry concerned with both of those matters at the same time. We are of the view that the issues can be properly resolved only by two separate public inquiries. Apart from involving the Tribunal in those excessively complex supplementary licence inquiries, the one process dealing with the two investigations to which I have referred would mean that prospective licensees for an independent licence would be required to prepare detailed applications for inquiries in doubtful areas on the off-chance- that is all it would be-that the Tribunal might determine that applications for an independent licence should be considered. The whole thing would be utterly confusing.

I revert to the main point; that is, that we are unfortunately unable to accept the amendment because to do so would negate the whole structure of the scheme, the very basis of which is that we take the current licensee and, in effect, invite him under the scheme to apply for a supplementary licence. If he does not do so then the field is open and the Minister may activate the machinery to bring the potential independent aspirants into the field. But there is no point in going on with the supplementary licence scheme if this proposed amendment were added to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown), may be quite lucid but his logic is rather twisted. I cannot see why we cannot add the words, 'or any other person' after the mention of:

SPEECH.PARA: The holder . . . or a consortium each member of which is the holder of such a licence may lodge with the Minister, in accordance with a form approved . . .

Would this not have the effect which we are trying to achieve, namely, that if somebody in a particular region or a particular area wants a second or further television licence, that is a television licence or a radio licence other than the ones that exists that person would not be able, under these provisions, to apply for that licence? The Minister made the point in his remarks that the power in the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill is given to the person with an existing licence who wants to apply for a supplementary licence. The Minister said: 'If that person does not apply then the field is open for others' . But why should an opportunity be given in the first instance to the person who has a licence in a particular town or city? Why not simply say: 'All right, if someone feels that they can make a go of a television station or a radio station , whether or not they happen to be the owner of an alternative station, why not simply allow them, under the provisions set out in the Bill, to apply and to meet the conditions required so that we can treat independents and those who are already owners in the same way'. The principle of equity is important here as is the principle of concentration of media ownership. There is nothing in proposed new section 82A which is inconsistent with adding the words which have been suggested by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones).
Amendments negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 9 (Consideration of applications by Tribunal).

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) I assume that he is seeking leave to move the amendments that have been circulated. I indicate to him that the circulated amendments (4) and (5) should more properly be one amendment because they refer to the same line of the Bill. Amendments (4) and (5) become amendment (4). Amendment (6), as circulated, becomes amendment (5).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 9, page 7, line 6, after 'licence' (second occurring) insert 'and the Tribunal has not refused to grant the licence by virtue of paragraph 83 (6) (g)'.
(4) Clause 9, page 7, line 19, after paragraph (e) insert the following paragraphs:
'(ea) by adding after paragraph (f) of sub-section (6) the following paragraph:

''(g) the Tribunal is satisfied that, where the licence is a supplementary licence, the granting of such licence would not result in undue concentration of influence, whether direct or indirect, on the applicant, having regard to the ownership and control of other media serving the area to be served by the licence.''.'.
'(eb) by inserting after sub-section (6) the following sub-section:

''(6A) In making a determination under sub-paragraph 83 (6) (e) (i), the Tribunal shall determine that a licence, other than a supplementary licence, would be reasonably likely to be commercially viable unless, on the basis of evidence supplied to the Tribunal, the Tribunal concludes otherwise.''.'.

Of the amendments (3) and (4), amendment (4) is the key amendment. I will just say something briefly by way of introduction of amendment (3). Amendment 3 deals with the case where the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has not found 'undue concentration'. It says that in that case the course is to follow the Bill's procedure; that is, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal goes on to determine whether an independent is viable and, if so, it recommends that the Minister invite an independent to apply for a licence. If not, it grants the supplementary licence. I want to say a few more words about amendment (4). Amendment (4) proposes to add in section 83 of the principal Act paragraph (g), which reads:

The tribunal is satisfied that, where the licence is a supplementary licence, the granting of such licence would not result in undue concentration of influence, whether direct or indirect, on the applicant, having regard to the ownership and control of other media serving the area to be served by the licence.

Amendment (4) says that a licence will not be given to a licensee if he is part of a cross-media grouping. It is meant to apply, for instance, in the case I mentioned in the second reading debate, to the Rouse case in Tasmania. We will not countenance the situation where all radio, television and Press in the town are owned by one person or company. This is unhealthy for diversity. It is also unhealthy for advertisers. We do not believe that this amendment would deny new services to country people. It would work as follows. Section 83 (6) of the principal Act in effect says that if the Tribunal holds an inquiry and a set of the conditions set out in section 6 paragraphs (a) to (f) are satisfied, the licence will be granted. The section applies to all licences and within the set paragraph (e) deals with supplementary licences. A new paragraph (e) is created in this Bill. Amendment (4), which would insert a new paragraph marked (ea), would set a seventh condition-that is, paragraph (g)-which says that for a supplementary licence an 'undue concentration', in effect, is to be frowned upon . Notice it is not undue concentration of ownership but undue concentration of influence. The term is used elsewhere in the Act, so we are not introducing a new concept.

Amendment (4) (eb) provides for evidence about commercial viability to be presented to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal if there is to be any challenge to the presumption of commercial viability. Amendment (5) treats the case where the Broadcasting Tribunal has found 'undue concentration'. It says that if a supplementary licence has been refused on those grounds the recommendation goes automatically to the Minister and he then invites application for an independent. In other words, it then abandons any test of viability.

It is important to emphasise that the inquiry ceases at that point. In our view it would be wrong to allow such a concentration of influence. It is contrary to the established philosophy along those lines originally set as far back as October 1935 when the first regulations against concentration of ownership in radio were made. It has had two-party support ever since. As recently as the time of the former Minister-who is now an aviation superstar-the Honourable A. A . Staley, this Government decided that FM was to be subject to the provisions along with AM radio, thus following the policy.

The arguments to be adduced in addition to those I have just given are, first, that if the licensee in a cross-ownership situation wants a supplementary licence badly enough he can divest himself of his other interests, when he will then be able to pass the 'undue influence' test; that is, he would be eligible or, alternatively, if he is cross-owned he ought to be viable enough to withstand any independent competition. Therefore, it is up to the independents to make a go of it. This is, paradoxically coming from us, a free enterprise argument if ever there was one. We are great advocates of free enterprise under certain limited circumstances. It is unlikely to be the established licensee who will be in trouble; it is much more likely to be the newcomer. If the argument that is put up here fails a Labor government would be prepared to consider in future other ways of bringing new services to the country.

I repeat what I said when I opened my remarks at the second reading stage. The flaw of this Bill is that it considers commercial services in isolation. There are other ways such as public or national broadcasting by which new services could be brought in. Unfortunately this Bill ignores these. In fact those alternative methods might well turn out to be more acceptable to many existing commercial broadcasters. I hardly need to restate the argument on the question of undue concentration. I simply say that we stand by the view that we need diversity and multiple sources of information in a society like ours. We believe that there should be competition and advertising and that it is very unhealthy for all outlets to be tied up by one group in one town of which probably the most outstanding examples in Australia would be Launceston and Mildura.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt whatsoever that the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) is motivated by some pure motives. The objective of competition of course is desirable but the Government is unable to accept the proposed amendments. I draw the honourable member's attention to amendment (4). At the start we could not accept this in any event because there seems to be a drafting fault which creates a double negative. Therefore it seems to achieve exactly the opposite of the effect which, I presume, is intended by the honourable member. If I read the opening words of the provision of the Broadcasting and Television Act and then add the clause proposed by the honourable member I think the fault will become apparent. Section 83 (6) of the Act provides:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal shall not refuse to grant a licence to a person unless it has held an inquiry into the grant of the licence and-
I now adopt the honourable member's words:
(g) the Tribunal is satisfied that, where the licence is a supplementary licence, the granting of such licence would not result in undue concentration of influence . . .

The honourable member intended to say that the licence would not be granted if there were an undue concentration of influence but in fact he has, with respect, said the opposite. As I have said section 83 (6) provides that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal shall not refuse to grant a licence unless a number of things happen. If one of the things that happens is that there is not undue concentration of influence presumably the intention would be that the licence would not be issued. However the result would be that the honourable member would have a licence issued in that case. It is probably just a drafting mistake but it illustrates one of the several problems that we have with the legislation .

The second matter is that the reference to, and I quote from the honourable member's amendment, any 'other media' does not have any definition. There would inevitably be difficulties of interpretation which may result in applications for judicial review and endless arguments if the Tribunal gave concentration of influence as a reason for any decision made against the grant of a licence. The fact that there is no definition of any other media would seem by itself to make this an unworkable amendment in our submission. In any event this is probably the substantial objection that we have. If one imposes this criteria it is, once again, at variance with the whole basis of the supplementary licence scheme. It is at variance because it would enable the Tribunal to refuse to grant a supplementary licence, which is what the whole exercise is about, on grounds of concentration of ownership even in those areas where the Tribunal has found that an independent licence would not be viable. Therefore, we could get to the stage where the Tribunal could find that an independent licence would not be viable and the result of that would be that the community would miss out on the service because the licence would be denied to the applicant on the grounds, presumably, of undue concentration of ownership. As I said, that could arise even where the Tribunal has found that an independent licence would not be viable to serve the area. Therefore, people would miss out on obtaining that service.

In respect of the other amendment-I am assuming that the honourable member has said what he proposes to say about it-we do not believe that it is appropriate that there should be this onus of proof provision worked into the legislation as it would result in an automatic Tribunal determination that an independent licence would be viable unless evidence to the countrary were offered. We think this is an undersirable way of putting it. In the first place, we say that the proposed amendment does not state what the standard of proof is that will be required by the Tribunal. As the applicant would attempt to supply and the Tribunal would require that evidence anyway, the amendment in our submission is unnecessary and probably unworkable.

Secondly, the proposed amendment overlooks the extensive powers and statutory obligations of the Tribunal to inform itself thoroughly on these matters. I refer the Committee to section 25 (1) and section 25 (2) of the Act. Section 25 (1) provides that:

The Tribunal shall, without regard to legal forms and solemnities, make a thorough investigation into all matters relevant to an inquiry under this Division, and may give all such directions and do all such things as the Tribunal considers are necessary or expedient for the expeditious and just hearing of the inquiry.
Section 25 (2) provides that:
The Tribunal is not bound by legal rules of evidence and may inform itself on any matter in such manner as it thinks fit.

Therefore, the Tribunal already has a very wide charter to look at a whole range of matters. The Government takes the view that, having gone down the path of giving extensive powers to the Tribunal and having vested the Tribunal with the responsibility of hearings and issuing licences to applicants, it is appropriate that it should be allowed to have a wide ambit, to have regard to the matters to which it wishes to have regard and to conduct its investigations in its own way, without shackling it by specific provisions relating to an onus of proof which would unnecessarily restrict its activities and the proper performance of its functions. As I said at the outset, although I am sure the honourable member is well motivated by the principles which he has espoused the Government is not able to accept the amendments proposed.
Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr N.A. Brown)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 14 October, on motion by Mr N.A. Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

Multiculturalism
Motion (by Mr N.A. Brown) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about what is happening in the field of ethnic affairs and multiculturalism in this country. Let me say at the outset that I am very disturbed at the attempts that have been made to blame the present economic crisis on immigration and, more seriously, on the role of migrant and ethnic communities in this country. We just cannot afford at a time of serious economic problems to have divisions arising because people are blaming ethnic or migrant communities for those problems. The fact is that for nearly 40 years now we have worked to build a multicultural and integrated Australia. In working towards this goal we have had difficulties and problems. Nevertheless, we have not attempted to divide one section from another or to blame one section of the community for our economic problems. Unfortunately, however, there are certain indications that this is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: What is more unfortunate is that certain prominent people in the community are attacking the very concept of multiculturalism and of a multicultural society. It is good that the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown) is in the House to answer the extraordinary statement by Professor Kramer, the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. She not only said that we can get rid of multicultural television but also virtually implied that multiculturalism had no place in our community. Statements of that kind by prominent individuals such as Professor Kramer are divisive and are calculated to attack the basis on which we have tried to build our society since the Second World War. They should be denounced. I am perturbed that that kind of claim has not been denounced by the Government.

The concept of a multicultural society was approved by this Government and by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in particular. The Government and certain of its spokespersons are backing away from that concept. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) recently made an absolute fool of himself at the national language conference when he tried to tell us--
