ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Illegal Export of Spitfire Aircraft

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following the conclusion of legal proceedings against certain parties concerning the illegal export from Australia of a rare Spitfire Mk VIII MV 154 will the Government pursue the return of this aircraft to Australia now that the case has finished.
(2) What steps are being taken to prevent the possible future illegal exporting of historical aircraft.
(3) Will the penalties for the export of historical aircraft or artifacts be increased.
(4) If the Government is not to proceed with attempts to recover the Spitfire, what are the grounds for not doing so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (4) The Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department has advised the Comptroller-General of Customs that an English court would probably not enforce a claim by the Commonwealth based on the forfeiture provisions of section 229 of the Customs Act 1901 and has advised against the instituting of proceedings in the United Kingdom. The then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs accepted that advice and I have found no reason to disagree with that decision. Proceedings to recover possession of the aircraft to which the honourable member refers will not be instituted in the United Kingdom.

(2) The Department of Industry and Commerce exercises control over such exports through the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. Offences or attempted offences against this legislation render the persons concerned subject to the penal provisions of the Customs Act including the forfeiture of the goods concerned.

It would seem that there are persons who are prepared to become involved in schemes to circumvent known Customs controls over the export of aircraft of historical interest. Assurance is given that the Department will investigate such attempts and take appropriate action wherever necessary.

(3) Yes. Legislation recently passed by Parliament, but not yet proclaimed, increases the penalties from $1,000 to $50,000 or three times the value of the goods (where the Court can determine the value), whichever is the greater.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Draw Poker Machines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are machines known as draw poker machines which are unlicensed and are used for gambling and payment of cash prizes operating in some hotels and clubs in Canberra.

(2) Has the attention of his Department and the Australian Federal Police been drawn to the use of these machines over a period of months; if so, why has effective action to control their use still not been taken.
(3) What action does he intend to take to bring these machines under the control of the ACT Gaming and Liquor Authority.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, draw poker machines are not required to be licensed.

(2) Yes. Although I earlier announced my support for the ACT House of Assembly' s recommendation to ban draw poker machines, I am not now convinced that such action would necessarily be in the best interests of the community. Accordingly I have referred the matter back to the House of Assembly for its earliest consideration.
(3) The involvement of the ACT Gaming and Liquor Authority will depend on the final decision made on whether draw poker machines should be permitted in the ACT.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Personal Care Subsidy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 29 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Commonwealth personal care subsidy paid only to institutions caring for old and frail and disabled persons; if so, why are (a) individuals caring for themselves and (b) persons caring for disabled people in private accommodation not eligible for this subsidy.

(2) Are parents caring for handicapped children at home eligible to receive the handicapped children's allowance of $18.25 whilst institutions are entitled to claim a personal care subsidy of $35 for the same children; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Personal Care Subsidy is paid only to organisations eligible under Part III of the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act which provide approved hostel accommodation and personal care services to their frail residents. The subsidy which was recently increased by 50 per cent to $30 a week , is intended to assist those organisations to employ sufficient staff in their hostels to assist the frail residents to live as independently as possible.

Individuals caring for themselves and people caring for aged or disabled people in private accommodation are not eligible for Personal Care Subsidy because they do not meet the requirements of the legislation.

The Commonwealth Department of Health administers the Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit under the National Health Act. This benefit is available to people who provide full time nursing care for chronically ill relatives in their homes: these patients would otherwise require admission to a nursing home. For a person to qualify for this benefit, the patient must:
be 16 years of age or over;
have a certificate from their doctor stating that, because of infirmity or illness, disease, incapacity or disability, they have a continuing need for nursing care;
be receiving adequate care from a registered nurse.
The current rate of benefit is $42 a fortnight and at 30 June 1982 there were approximately 18,000 approved beneficiaries.

There is also an attendant care pilot scheme being developed by the Department of Social Security which was allocated $100,000 for this purpose in the 1982-83 Budget. This pilot will be administered as part of the Handicapped Persons Welfare Program Up-grading Scheme. The Attendant Care Scheme will investigate the provision of alternative modes of personal care services to severely handicapped people who live in their own homes.

(2) The maximum rate of handicapped child's allowance currently payable is $85 a month. The allowance was introduced to assist parents who provide constant care and attention to their child where the child is severely or substantially handicapped and is cared for in the family home rather than in an institution. Handicapped children's benefit is currently paid at the rate of $5 per day. It is payable to approved charitable or religious organisations in respect of each handicapped child under the age of 16 who is accommodated in the residential centre conducted by the organisation. The amount of the benefit is required to be deducted from the account sent to the child's parents.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Crisis Accommodation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Prime Minister, in his policy speech on 30 September 1980, promise to establish crisis accommodation for families in distress.
(2) If so, when was this promise implemented and in what form.
(3) What was the Commonwealth's appropriation and spending on this program in ( a) 1980-81 and (b) 1981-82.
(4) How many families were assisted in each year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) On 24 February 1982 in a joint news release with the then Minister for Housing and Construction, the Hon. D. T. McVeigh, I announced the new Crisis Accommodation for Families in Distress Program. The press release indicated that the funds allocated could be used by the States, the Northern Territory and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd for the construction, purchase, or leasing of suitable dwellings for crisis accommodation for families.
(3) (a) 1980-81 Appropriation-Nil, Expenditure-Nil; (b) 1981-82 Appropriation-$ 2m, Expenditure-$2m.
In addition, I announced on 1 October 1982 the distribution of the $4m allocated for crisis accommodation by the Budget for 1982-83.

(4) Information on the number of families assisted is not available. However in 1981-82 the States, Northern Territory and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd used the $2m to: purchase 30 dwellings; construct 1 dwelling; lease about 180 dwellings; and provide accommodation for 13 additional beds in an Aboriginal Hostel.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Accounting Standards Review Board

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to my repeated questions regarding the urgent need to set up an Accounting Standards Review Board, can the Attorney-General intimate whether the submissions to the National Companies and Securities Commission relating to the Board have been completed.
(2) Has the Commission completed its findings; if so, has a report been made; if not, when will a report be made.
(3) Will the Commission's report be tabled in the Parliament.

(4) Is the National Companies and Securities Commission seeking information by way of submissions regarding the content of the revamped Schedule 9, that is, a re-listed old Schedule 7; if so, for what purpose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, at its meeting on 20 November 1981, directed the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to publicly expose until 31 March 1982 its proposals in relation to an Accounting Standards Review Board. The NCSC subsequently issued a media release on 26 November 1981 setting out its proposals for the establishment of such a Board. Further background on these proposals is contained in the answer given in this House by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs on 29 October 1981 to Question No. 2694 from the honourable member (Hansard, page 2798).
(2) The NCSC has advised that it expects its report to be available for consideration by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities at its next meeting.
(3) It would be undesirable to make a decision on tabling the report until the Ministerial Council has had an opportunity to consider the issues raised in the report.

(4) The NCSC, on 12 May 1982, sought submissions by 16 August 1982 from a number of interested persons on the form and content of Schedule 7 to the Companies Regulations. In seeking submissions, the NCSC indicated that it wished to develop proposals for:
(i) making information contained in the published financial statements of companies more accessible and comprehensible;
(ii) removing inconsistencies, imprecision or ambiguity in the requirements;
(iii) amending requirements which may be inconsistent with recognised accounting standards; and
(iv) establishing a process for the continuous future scrutiny and, where necessary, revision of the requirements.
Any amendments to the regulations will be made following consideration by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aborigines at Robinvale, Victoria

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Human Rights Commission, or any other body under his control, made any investigation of allegations of racism directed towards Aborigines in the town of Robinvale, Victoria, as reported on the ABC TV program Nationwide, on 15 March 1982.

(2) If so, (a) who made the investigation, (b) has the Government been furnished with any report of that investigation and, if so, when and (c) what recommendations have been made to the Government following that investigation.
(3) Can the Attorney-General now state what further action the Government proposes to take in respect of this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) In response to requests from the Aboriginal community in Robinvale to the Commissioner for Community relations, two officers of the Human Rights Commission visited Robinvale, Victoria, in the course of conciliation field trips made to various centres in Victoria and Southern New South Wales during the period 4-16 May 1982 and met with a number of people in Robinvale including some who had been involved in the issues which had been the subject of the Nationwide program.

The Human Rights Commission has informed me that it appeared that there were no complaints which needed to be pursued under the Racial Discrimination Act but the team did what it could to assist in restoring good community relations in the town.
Further visits were made during the period 13-16 June 1982 by the team during which it was informed by the Aboriginal community that the situation was satisfactory.

(3) No further action is at present considered by the Human Rights Commission to be required but contact is, I understand, being maintained with members of the community in Robinvale as is the practice in relation to centres which have made complaints to the Commissioner.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Children Illegally Taken out of Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many children have been illegally taken out of Australia in each of the past 5 years.
(2) Is the Attorney-General able to give the figures on the basis of country of origin of the abducting parent.
(3) How many claims for legal aid have been (a) lodged and (b) granted in connection with these cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that with regard to parts (1) and (2) of the honourable member's question, no details are kept of the number of children illegally taken out of Australia. I am therefore unable to give the figures requested nor am I able to give figures in relation to the country of origin of the abducting parent.

With regard however to part (3) of the question which concerns the number of claims for legal aid lodged and granted in connection with children being taken illegally from the country, I am advised that during the period 1977-1979 there were 9 applications for aid, 3 of which received act of grace payments recommended by the Attorney-General and approved by the Minister for Finance.

In August 1979 the Government introduced the Overseas Custody (Child Removal) Scheme to provide assistance to parents whose children have been removed from Australia illegally. Since then 73 applications for assistance under the Scheme have been lodged of which 18 have been granted. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Tapping: Airport Calls

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are any telephone calls made to, or from, any of Australia's airports tapped.
(2) If so, which airports are affected, and to what extent.
(3) Under whose authorisation and in what manner is this surveillance made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The interception of a telephone communication is illegal unless done pursuant to a warrant issued under the Telecommunications ( Interception) Act 1979 to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization or the Australian Federal Police.

That Act provides that, in certain circumstances related to security, the Attorney-General may authorise the Australian Security Intelligence Organization to intercept telecommunications. It also provides that a judge (as defined) may authorise the Australian Federal Police to intercept telecommunications in certain circumstances relating to the investigation of narcotic offences.
It is not the practice of the Government to provide information concerning telephone interceptions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Takeovers Code: Resolution of Disputes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Acting Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the normal judicial process inappropriate for the authoritative and expeditious resolution of disputes which arise under the National Takeovers Code .
(2) Is it a fact that parties to a takeover litigation may have to wait for more than 6 months for the final resolution of a dispute by the High Court.

(3) Will the Attorney-General initiate urgent discussions within the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities with a view to setting up an expert tribunal to deal effectively and expeditiously with all disputes arising under the Takeovers Code.

(4) Is it a fact that, because of the lengthy delays involved, the final appellate court, or for that matter any appellate court, might find it impracticable to grant the relief sought by a plaintiff in takeover litigation even though the plaintiff's legal arguments are accepted.

(5) Can the Attorney-General say whether parties to takeover litigation with very meritorious cases have been forced to abandon appeals from dubious single judge decisions because delays within the appellate court system appear to make it extraordinarily difficult for an appellate court to satisfactorily unscramble a takeover.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) While legislation governing takeovers of companies needs to take account of considerations such as those mentioned by the honourable member and to minimise delays which are avoidable, it has to be borne in mind that takeovers involve the rights of individuals and that they give rise to questions as to whether those rights have been breached. The resolution of such questions is properly a matter for the courts and the judicial process. I am not prepared to propose to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities that such questions be determined by an administrative body.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Speaker of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly: Priority of Legislation for Appointment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australan Capital Territory Fire Brigade

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 15 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the duties of the following officers of the ACT Fire Brigade (a) Fire Commissioner, (b) Deputy Fire Commissioner, (c) Superintendent and (d) District Officers.
(2) In the case of the Deputy Fire Commissioner, what duties were formerly performed by the (a) Commissioner and (b) Superintendent.
(3) What is the estimated cost of creating the additional position of Deputy Fire Commissioner.

(4) Was this position made necessary (a) by a Government decision to provide an additional political appointee to overcome the need for a career officer to act as Commissioner on occasions or (b) because the work load of the Commissioner and the Superintendent were excessive.
(5) Have requests for lifting of staff ceilings been received.
(6) Why is the salary of the Deputy Commissioner lower than that of the Superintendent.
(7) Did (a) the Commissioner or (b) the Superintendent request relief from an excessive work load.
(8) What staff will be assigned to the Deputy Commissioner.
(9) Will these personnel be in addition to the staff of the (a) Commissioner and (b) Superintendent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The duties of the members are:
(a) Fire Commissioner: general control and management of the Fire Brigade.
(b) Deputy Commissioner: assist the Commissioner with the general control and management of the Fire Brigade.
(c) Superintendent: the duties of the Superintendent will be:
1. Oversight the work of the Fire Prevention, Firefighting and Service Maintenance Sections.

2. Evaluate new equipment and submit for ratification to Commissioner findings based on-(a)practicability, (b) cost analysis, (c) interchange with existing equipment and (d) involvement connected with training, stowage, etc.
3. Process returns relating to personnel that is Long Service Leave, Sick Leave , Compassionate Leave, etc.
4. Oversight station and roster changes for personnel.
5. As directed, liaise with various organisations on the implementation of policy established by the Commissioner.
6. Attend and assume command of fires and emergent happenings involving life risk and any other incident deemed necessary until the arrival of a more senior officer.
7. Oversight examinations.
8. Responsible to Commissioner for the welfare of personnel.
9. Prepare, subject to direction, reviews of projected needs for the Brigade.
10. If required, represent the Commissioner at conferences, seminars, functions , etc.
11. Determine, prior to final submittal to the Commissioner, the gravity of all discipline charges associated with all personnel employed by the Brigade.
12. Keep Commissioner fully informed of all fires, offences against discipline and the general function of the day to day operations of the Brigade.
(d) District Officer: while on duty shall:
1. Have charge of the District or Section which has been assigned.
2. Attend fires and take control until the arrival of a more senior officer.
3. Check and pass reports and requisitions for repairs and supplies.
4. Be responsible for the proper working of the assigned District or Section and the maintenance of strict discipline.
5. Perform all other duties required as a District Officer or which may be expressly assigned.
(2) The duties of the Commissioner are unchanged as above. The Superintendent's duties as outlined in 1 (c) are substantially the same.

The Deputy Commissioner will assist the Commissioner over the full range of the Commissioner's functions and it is expected the Deputy Commissioner will deputise for the Commissioner at more important conferences and meetings and assist with industrial relations matters.

(3) The cost of the position when staffed would be in the vicinity of $65,000 ( includes salary and oncost charges). Other costs associated with the establishing of the additional position are insignificant.
(4) (a) No. (b) The position was necessary because of the workload of the position of Commissioner.

(6) In anticipation of the creation of the position of Deputy Commissioner, the Remuneration Tribunal determined a salary as at 7 June 1982. The Superintendent' s salary was increased by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in a variation to the Fire Brigade Employees (ACT) Award 1975 handed down on 1 July 1982.
(7) The Commissioner requested a position of Deputy Commissioner because of the top management workload.
(8) No personal staff as such will be assigned to the Deputy Commissioner. However, as the Deputy of the Commissioner, the full resources of the Brigade will be available.
(9) Not applicable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Naturalisation Ceremonies in the Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who is empowered to conduct naturalisation ceremonies in the ACT.
(2) Who has the authority to administer the citizenship oath in the ACT.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ACT House of Assembly conducts Australian citizenship ceremonies in the ACT with the agreement of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is the normal practice throughout Australia for citizenship ceremonies held in public to be conducted by local government authorities. Delegated officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the ACT are also empowered to conduct citizenship ceremonies.

(2) The Australian Citizenship Act provides that oaths and affirmations of allegiance may be taken or made before a judge of a Federal court or a judge or magistrate holding office under the law of a State or Territory or before a person delegated by the Minister. Apart from delegated officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, persons in the following positions are delegated to administer the citizenship oath/affirmation of allegiance:
The Leader of the House, ACT House of Assembly;
The Minority Leader, ACT House of Assembly;
The Chairman of Committees, ACT House of Assembly.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Health Promotion Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 16 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that no funds were allocated to the National Health Promotion Program in the 1982-83 Budget.
(2) Is it also a fact that only $140,000 was spent out of the $500,000 appropriated for the Program in 1981-82.

(3) If so, does this mean that the Government is abandoning its role in the field of health promotion despite the promise of the Prime Minister in his policy speech of 30 September 1980 and his speech to the ANU Public Affairs conference on Health Policy in which he referred to the promotion of individual health as the front line of health care; if not, what is the future Commonwealth role in this field.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. Funds for the National Health Promotion Program were frozen in February 1982 as part of a general restraint of expenditure across a wide range of Government programs and activities.

The Government is concerned about promoting the health of individuals and encouraging Australians to value good health as an asset which is worth achieving and maintaining. Just as health services are mainly provided by States so too health promotion is primarily the responsibility of States. This will not , however, preclude the Commonwealth from taking further initiatives in this most important side of health care as and when the appropriate time and need arises.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority: Connection of Solar Hot Water Systems to Off-Peak Supply

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 21 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he received representations protesting against the ACT Electricity Authority's ACTEA decision to connect solar hot water systems compulsorily only to Off-Peak supply.

(2) Has he examined the report of the ACT House of Assembly Standing Committee on City Management in which the committee criticises this decision and draws attention to the large number of units that have not been tested by the ACTEA.
(3) Why was the decision to restrict solar hot water services only to Off-Peak supply made.
(4) Why does this restriction not apply to other systems connected to Off-Peak supply.
(5) Has he made any response to the findings of the committee; if so, what was the reponse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The report by the ACT House of Assembly's Standing Committee on City Management, which contains a number of recommendations, was presented in the Assembly on 25 October 1982 and has now been referred to me.
I am currently studying the contents of the report.
(3) This decision was made in the interest of a fair distribution of costs across the whole spectrum of electricity consumers.

The Authority is billed for bulk supply of electricity on the basis of both the energy consumed and the highest demand recorded during the month. In addition, the Authority must provide plant capacity equal to or greater than the highest consumer demand likely to occur within the ACT on the coldest day.

Except for a small number of very large customers who are billed for both energy and demand, the average consumer is billed only for the energy used. Therefore the tariff charged must be structured so that costs associated with the demand generated and the plant installed are recovered as well as the energy consumed.

Charges for electricity are constructed on the basis of a reasonable expectation that electricity will be consumed both during and outside peak demand times. While non-solar hot water heaters add significantly to peak demand , they operate ouside peak hours often enough for the Authority to recover costs .

Solar Water Heaters, on the other hand, while adding to the peak demand, do not require electric boosting during daylight hours. This, as a consequence, denies the Authority a significant amount of potential revenue and requires the shortfall to be subsidised by all other classes of consumers in the ACT. The Authority, therefore, considers that connection to Off-Peak supply is the fairest method of ensuring that Solar Systems 'pay their way'.

The Authority believes very strongly in energy conservation and applauds the Solar Heating Industry for its resourcefulness and dedication. However, the cost of providing standby boosting for Solar Water Heaters should not be borne by those not fortunate enough to afford the capital cost of their own Solar System.
(4) The restriction does apply to other systems connected to off-peak supply. The ACTEA Schedule of Charges provides that with Off-Peak Water Heating Charge ' booster elements are not permitted'.
(5) See my answer to question (2).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Appropriation for Marine and General Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 22 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: In relation to item 972:4:03 of Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1982-83 concerning marine and general services, (a) what estimate can be provided of the real change in the provision made for this item in 1982-83 compared to 1981-82 and (b ) what are the reasons for this change.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) The expenditure during 1981-82 was $4,847,000 and the estimated expenditure for 1982-83 is $4,740,000. This means that there is an estimated marginal decrease in expenditure for 1982-83. Assuming that there will be an element of inflation during 1982-83, the estimated marginal decrease represents a decrease in real terms. It is not possible however to provide an estimate of the real change in the provision made in 1982-83 compared to 1981-82, mainly because this capital expenditure largely results from ongoing programmes with cash flows varying from year to year depending on manufacturing schedules amongst other things. For example the installation of light vessels in Bass Strait will continue in 1982-83 whereas bulk cash payments against this project were made in 1981-82.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Withdrawal of Australian Battalion from Singapore in 1974

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the address by the Prime Minister to the National RSL Congress on 15 September 1982 in which he said that the decision to withdraw the Australian battalion from Singapore in 1974 was one of the great mistakes in Australian defence decisions.
(2) Why has this alleged mistake not been rectified previously.
(3) Does he propose to deploy a similar sized unit to Singapore, if not, why not.
(4) Has he had discussions with the governments of either Malaysia or Singapore for a deployment of this kind; if so, what has been their response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Government while in opposition made clear its intention to discuss with its Five Power partners the question of regional defence co-operation. In view of the lapse of time between the withdrawal of the main body of the battalion at the end of 1973 and the return to office of the present Government in 1976, and the substantial re-arrangements and accommodations that were forced on the Singapore Government and our other partners by the withdrawal of the battalion, the Government has sought other practical means to demonstrate our willingness to co-operate with neighbouring countries to enhance the security of the region. Examples include:
A revitalisation of the Five Power Defence Arrangements.
An Expansion of Defence Co-operation programs.
An increase in combined exercises with our South East Asian neighbours.
Provision of access by Singapore to training areas in Australia.
(3) and (4) See (2) above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Leopard Tank

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is an efficiency audit of the management of the Leopard tank capability being undertaken by the Auditor- General.
(2) When did the audit commence.
(3) What personnel have been, and are currently involved in the audit and what was and is their public service classification.
(4) What sections of the Department of Defence have been interviewed in connection with the audit.
(5) What aspects of the Leopard program have been studied during the investigations.
(6) How much has the audit cost.
(7) When will the final report be presented to the House and what aspects of the program will be reported upon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The efficiency audit investigation began in April 1980.
(3) During the investigation phase of the audit the audit team comprised one Class 11 officer, two Class 9 officers and one Class 7 officer.
As at 23 September 1982, one Class 7 officer was engaged on the audit, report editing being undertaken by Audit Office management.

(4) During the course of the audit, enquiries were undertaken within elements of the Department of Defence Central Office, the Army Office, Logistics Command, Training Command and Field Force Command.

(5) The audit examined management and support systems relevant to the role of the Leopard tank capability. It extended to both service and departmental activities including personnel and training, supply and support systems and engineering support.
(6) Up to and including 23 September 1982 the audit has cost $127,758.
(7) A report on the audit is expected to be presented to the Parliament during the Autumn Session 1983. However, the final content of the report has not yet been determined.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trade Practices Commission: Consumer Protection Investigations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Acting Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Trade Practices Commission, in its 1981-82 Annual Report, advise that one effect of the Ministerial Direction of 25 May 1981 has been that the Commission is unable to take the first initiative in investigations in relation to consumer protection.

(2) Did the Commission also advise that the very tight control of investigations has meant that some matters have necessarily come to the Commission inadequately developed and with too little information.

(3) Has the Government provided the Commission with any additional resources to enable it to (a) undertake investigations at its own initiative and (b) ensure that investigations are fully and adequately prepared for the Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Trade Practices Commission advised that until recently the tight control, by which staff needed the Commission's approval for each investigation, and also the need to institute cases within twelve months, meant that some matters could not be taken up with the companies concerned so that they came to the Commission inadequately developed and with too little information. The TPC has now taken administrative steps to improve this situation by delegating to senior staff the power to seek initial comments from the company complained of.

(3) The Government keeps under notice both the impact of the Direction and the level of staffing in the Commission to ensure that it is able to carry out its responsibilities under the Trade Practices Act. Additional resources have not been required because:

(a) The Ministerial Direction of 25 May 1981 required the Trade Practices Commission to confine its consumer protection investigations to matters raising issues of importance at the national level and where such matters are brought to its attention by another person. This Direction accords with the Government's decisions announced by the Prime Minister on the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(b) As noted above, the Commission has now taken administrative steps to speed up the development of possible cases.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Navy: Recruitment of British Officers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Royal Australian Navy sent a recruiting team to Britain to seek Royal Navy officers for the RAN.
(2) If so, how many officers are being sought.
(3) What technical or special requirements are needed that cannot be found amongst Australian naval personnel.
(4) Why are non-commissioned ranks in the RAN denied the opportunity for promotion to fill these positions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Two RAN officers have been sent to the United Kingdom to expedite and streamline procedures for the induction into the RAN of former Royal Navy officers who have already applied to transfer to the RAN. These two officers are not a recruiting team and they have been directed not to undertake any active recruiting. The requirement for their visit to the UK arose because of the inability of the Australian High Commission to process ex-RN officer entrants to the RAN following recent staffing reductions.

(2) The RAN is not actively seeking RN or ex-RN officer entrants. There are at present 43 RN or ex-RN officers who have been given conditional approval to enter the RAN and unsolicited applications continue to be received.

(3) RN or ex-RN officers being inducted into the RAN are principally engineers or maritime warfare specialists of the requisite rank and experience required for unfilled billets in the RAN. There is a world wide shortage of engineers and this is in part responsible for the RAN shortages. Appropriately trained and experienced naval specialists are not available from within the RAN's own ranks.

(4) Non commissioned ranks in the RAN are not being denied any opportunity for promotion because of these measures. Initial offers of service to ex-RN officers guarantee neither permanency of employment nor promotion and with very few exceptions, these ex-RN officers serve in the RAN for limited periods and without career prospects. The RAN is continually striving to enhance the career prospects for both eligible non commissioned ranks and its junior officers but such is the complexity of modern maritime warfare that it is not possible to by- pass either essential training or experience during career progression if Australia's navy is to remain a credible fighting force with its officers demonstrating professional competence.

(2) Where personnel have not qualified for Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits retirement what will be the financial terms applied to their retrenchments.
(3) Why are these officers not capable of filling vacancies occurring in other sections of the RAN.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What materials and equipment currently in use in the Minister's Department or bodies under the Minister's control are known to contain polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the dangers associated with the use of PCBs.

(3) What (a) statutory and (b) advisory conditions exist for the purpose of monitoring all introduction, use, transport and disposal of PCBs, and what arrangements are currently in existence for policing statutory conditions.
(4) What methods of storage and disposal are used for materials and equipment containing PCBs when those items become redundant or useless.

(5) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to any contamination of the environment by PCBs which may be wholly or partly due to the use, etc., of PCBs by the Minister's Department or bodies under the Minister's control; if so, what are the details.

(6) Has the Minister taken any steps to ensure that all employees under the Minister's control are fully aware of the dangers of PCBs; if so, what are the details; if not, will the Minister now do so; if the Minister will not do so, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The only equipment in use within the Department known to contain PCBs are two transformers installed at Repatriation General Hospital, Hobart, which are maintained by the Department of Transport and Construction.
(2) Yes.

(3) Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations prohibit the importation of polychlorinated biphenyls, terphenyls and other polyphenyls unless the permission of the Minister for Industry and Commerce has been granted. This regulation has been in force since 1973. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Education: Discipline

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the 1982 direction of the Government of Eire, which followed the example of most European Governments, that, in National Schools, (a) teachers should have a lively regard for the improvement of their pupils, treat them with kindness combined with firmness and should aim at governing them through their affections and reason, and not by harshness and severity, (b) ridicule, sarcasm or remarks likely to undermine a pupil's self-confidence should not be used in any circumstances, (c) the use of corporal punshiment should be forbidden, and (d) any teacher who contravened these rules would be regarded as guilty of conduct unbefitting a teacher and subject to severe disciplinary action.

(2) Has the Minister's attention also been drawn to the reports of spectacular success in the use of self-discipline by teachers in overcoming problems of difficult pupils in Education for Tomorrow's World, by Henden, Forland and Fraenki, published in 1970 by Grosvenor Books, London.
(3) Will Australia follow Ireland's example; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) As my predecessor indicated in his reply to Question No. 3954 from the honourable member earlier this year, the Commonwealth's direct involvement in the administration of schools is limited to the Australian Capital Territory. The ACT Schools Authority has urged all ACT government schools to work towards the abolition of physical punishment.
ACT Government schools each have a school board which determines educational policy and philosophy for the school, operating within the general directions set by the ACT Schools Authority.

Schools in the ACT generally wish to be known for their caring relationships, where the teachers are aware of children's needs and guide and promote the whole development of each child, where the teacher's respect for the child as a person cultivates in him or her the desire to learn, and where caring and respect is mutual between all members of the school community.

As far as government schools in the States and non-government schools are concerned these are matters for the respective State and non-government school authorities to determine. However, I believe that in all schools, teachers who take a professional approach to their duties would adhere to humanitarian principles.

COMMITTEE FOR THE ALLOCATION OF LOAN FUNDS TO REFUGEES IN CENTRES (CALFRIC)

Under the CALFRIC loan scheme, funds from my Department's appropriation are allocated to a fund operated by the Committee for the Allocation of Loan Funds to Refugees in Centres (CALFRIC). This Committee makes small, interest-free loans (up to $600) to refugees, to assist them with the expenses of moving out of migrant centres into the community. Money from repayments on loans is recycled via the CALFRIC fund and lent to other refugees. The Committee comprises representatives of the following voluntary agencies:
The Salvation Army
Austcare
Indo China Refugee Association (Australia)
The Saint Vincent de Paul Society
Australian Council of Churches
Australian Council of Social Services;
as well as of Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services and of my Department.
In 1981-82, the Government allocated a further $200,000 to the CALFRIC loan fund bringing to $1.213m the total Commonwealth contribution.

My Department also makes payments via the Clothing Reimbursement Scheme to reimburse voluntary agencies for the cost of providing essential clothing and personal requisites to refugees who lack these items when they arrive in Australia. A detailed breakdown of all accounts submitted for payment under this scheme in 1981-82 would require an examination of every single claim, and would make demands of staffing resources which I am not prepared to authorise. The major agencies participating in the scheme were:
Saint Vincent de Paul Society
The Salvation Army
Red Cross
The Smith Family
Seventh Day Adventist Church
Hobart City Mission.

In addition to those agencies, however, small community groups participating in the Community Refugee Settlement Scheme are eligible to claim reimbursement for clothing provided to refugees who bypass migrant centres and go straight into the community under that scheme; details of those groups are not readily available.
A total of $199,850 was paid to voluntary agencies under this scheme in 1981-82 .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article on page 21 of the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 June 1982 concerning Tan Sri Khoo Teck Puat.
(2) How many applications for permanent residence under the Business Migration category have been approved each year since the inception of this scheme.
(3) Was Tan Sri Khoo Teck Puat granted entry to Australia under this scheme.
(4) Can foreign nationals purchase permanent residence under this program by purchasing Australian companies or businesses.
(5) Has his attention been drawn to the inequity of such a scheme.
(6) How many permanent resident visa holders travelled overseas and returned to Australia last year.
(7) What is the minimum period of residence required in Australia each year to return with permanent residence status.
(8) Are some permanent residence visa holders only holidaying in Australia each year to retain their permanent resident status while conducting their normal lives and business in other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Business Migration Program commenced on 19 April 1982. It superseded the previous entrepreneur migration category which had been in operation since November 1976. Arrivals of entrepreneurial migrants and business migrants in the last three financial years are as follows: 1979-80-78
(3) Yes. Tan Sri Khoo Teck Puat was approved under the entrepreneur migration category in 1981.

(4) and (5) No. People selected under the former entrepreneurial category and the Business Migration Program are expected to settle in Australia and to satisfy normal migration requirements. The business proposal submitted by the applicant and the likely benefits of the proposal to Australia form important parts of consideration of the application.

(6) During 1981, 221,473 persons with resident status departed. Of these 10,719 were long term residents (i.e. one year or more) and the remaining 212,754 were short term residents (i.e. less than one year).
For the same period, 212,765 persons with resident status returned to Australia . This figure comprised 15,303 long term residents and 197,460 short term residents.

It is not possible to extract from these figures the number of persons who may have departed and returned during the course of the year. The totals would also include persons who may have departed and returned more than once.
Separate statistics are not maintained on resident businessmen who travel in and out of Australia.
(7) Persons with resident status in Australia under the Migration Program may remain overseas for periods up to, but not normally exceeding:
three years where the person has lived in Australia for at least 12 months.
one year where the person has lived in Australia for less than 12 months.

(8) Business migrants are expected to settle permanently in Australia. However, some businessmen need to visit other countries in connection with their business affairs. In general, reasons for leaving Australia must be consistent with the principle that there is a genuine intention to settle in Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Service: Employment Conditions of Casual Teachers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement by the Industrial Commissioner of NSW, issued on 18 August 1982, strongly critical of the conditions under which casual full-time teachers in the Adult Migrant Education Service are employed compared to the 77 permanent teachers in the service.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to a statement by Mr Justice Bauer that ( a) the evidence is that the casual full-time teachers do the same work and participate in teaching education preparation and developments in the various centres and for all intents and purposes do the same work as if they were permanent employees and (b) it might reasonably be said that the conditions of employment result in the casual, full-time teachers subsidising the Adult Migrant Education Scheme.
(3) If so will he respond to the views expressed in the Industrial Commission by releasing the funds necessary to make these casual teaching positions permanent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) I have read the statement of Mr Justice Bauer of the NSW Industrial Commission which refers to the conditions of casual teachers employed for 20 hours per week in the NSW Adult Migrant Education Service.

I have noted that the transcript of the hearing cites instances of casual teachers undertaking activities which extend the time that they spend at the Adult Migrant Education Centre beyond 20 hours per week. The responsibilities of these casual teachers has been compared by Mr Justice Bauer with the permanent teachers who are on duty for 30 hours per week.

To ensure an adequate degree of flexibility in the size and distribution of the Adult Migrant Education Service to match the changing composition and needs of the non-English speaking migrant intake, it is desirable to have a balance of permanent and casual teachers. As at 15 September 1982, there were 115 permanent teacher positions in the NSW Adult Migrant Education Service. In response to approaches from the NSW Minister for Education, I have agreed to provide funding for the conversion of an additional 30 positions from casual to permanent.

Within the current appropriations further funds cannot be provided to convert casual positions to permanent ones without reducing the total number of hours of English language instruction available to migrants, or other important services. I have proposed adjustments to the teaching arrangements to make it possible to convert further positions from casual to permanent.

At the same time I have undertaken to examine closely the basis for future funding of permanent teacher positions with particular attention to the appropriate proportion of permanent teachers, given the need for a mix of permanent and casual staff. This is a matter which has national implications and I have indicated to the NSW Minister for Education that the Commonwealth will need to take account of these national implications in responding further to approaches from NSW.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Housing Assistance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was $20m promised by the Government in its March housing assistance package to assist rent and mortgage payers in genuine distress.
(2) Was this decision announced again in the August Budget statement by the Treasurer as the Mortgage and Rent Relief Program; if so, why.

(3) Is it a fact that, at the time this question was submitted, there has been a 7 month delay in implementing the program despite it originally being intended to help people in distress in March 1982.

(4) Is the program dependent on State Government co-operation; if so, what correspondence did the Government enter into with the States immediately after the March announcement to secure co-operation.
(5) What are the details of the correspondence between the Commonwealth and the Queensland Government.
(6) What assurance can he give that mortgage and rent payers in genuine distress in March 1982 have not been forgotten.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes, for the purpose of appropriation. Appropriation Bill No. 2 shows the sum of $20m as grants by the Commonwealth to the States and Territories for the Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme.

(3) On 18 March 1982, it was announced that discussions would be held with the States, Northern Territory and ACT on introduction from 1982-83 of a joint Commonwealth and State Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme. These discussions commenced at the Commonwealth and State Housing Ministers' Conference in Melbourne on 26 March. Commonwealth and State officials then met to discuss the development of the program.
As a result of these discussions a formal proposal for the scheme was developed and this formed the basis of the formal offer made to the States on 27 August 1982.

The States and Territories are responsible for the administration of the scheme , including the form of assistance to be provided and the date of commencement. The scheme is now operating in most States/Territories.

(4) Yes, the former Minister for Housing and Construction, the Hon. D. T. McVeigh, wrote to each State/Territory Housing Minister on 22 March 1982. This letter proposed the commencement of discussions between the Commonwealth and States and Territories at the Commonwealth and State Housing Ministers' meeting in Melbourne on 26 March.

(5) As indicated, the former Minister for Housing and Construction wrote to the Queensland Minister for Works and Housing, the Hon. C. Wharton, MLA, on 22 March 1982 and I wrote to him making a formal offer on the scheme on 27 August 1982.

In his response to the offer on 8 September, Mr Wharton advised that it would be necessary for him to refer the matter to the Queensland Cabinet for consideration before he could formally respond. At the time of preparation of this answer a formal reply had not been received.
(6) As noted above, a formal offer to the States and Territories has been made, and the scheme is already operating in most States and Territories.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Immigration Status

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 28 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article by Mr Phillip Adams in the Bulletin of 21 September, 1982 concerning the immigration status of Mr Michael Friedrich and his family?
(2) If so, have the allegations made in the article been investigated.
(3) What action has been taken on Mr Friedrich's application for permanent resident status?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) I asked my Department for a detailed report so that I could thoroughly review Mr Friedrich's case.

The facts concerning Mr Friedrich are as follows: Mr Friedrich and his family arrived as visitors on 2 October 1981. Four days later in direct contravention of the undertakings they signed when they applied for their visitors visas, the Friedrich's sought permanent residence.
Mr Friedrich argued that because he had helped people escape from East Germany his life was in danger in his home country of West Germany.

In response to this my Department contacted the Australian Embassy in West Germany; the West German authorities confirmed that Mr Friedrich was an 'escape helper' but that he was in no danger while he remained in West Germany.
The fact that Mr Friedrich returned to West Berlin after he had arrived in Australia confirms this.

At the time I reviewed the case Mr Friedrich had not applied for refugee status in Australia. He subsequently did so through his solicitors. I am mindful of Australia's obligations under the Refugee Convention and the proud record this country has of accepting genuine refugees over past decades. I have asked the Determination of Refugee Status (DORS) Committee to examine his claim to be a refugee and report to me.
Mr Friedrich has been assessed in terms of Section 6A of the Migration Act ( refugee status apart) and found not to be eligible for the grant of permanent residence under this provision.

I am satisfied that apart from the question of refugee status, which is soon to be decided, there is no justification for the Friedrich family to remain in Australia. I will advise the honourable member of my final decision once I have the report of the DORS Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Mr Wallenberg's heroism in saving the lives of large numbers of potential victims of Nazi persecutions in Hungary during World War II is well- known and has been widely acknowledged. It is correct that he performed these deeds while serving at the Swedish Embassy in Budapest.
(2) Yes.

(3) Yes. The Government is aware of reports that Mr Wallenberg is alive and that he has been seen in Soviet prisons. Sweden continues to pursue the Wallenberg case with the Soviet authorities, who so far have done no more than repeat their claim that Mr Wallenberg died in prison in 1947.

(4) and (5) The Australian Government fully supports the efforts of Sweden to have the case re-examined by the Soviet authorities. Because the Australian Government has no direct standing in the matter, however, there has been little opportunity for us to make an effective intervention. The matter is basically the concern of the Swedish and Soviet Governments and for the time being it is felt that Sweden is best placed to press for a more satisfactory response from the Soviet authorities. The Government is keeping in touch with developments, nonetheless, and remains willing to take whatever opportunities may arise, in multilateral forums particularly, to support Sweden's efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1982 (Hansard, page 178) Mr Moore asked me, as the Acting Attorney-General, the following question without notice:

He would be aware also that to form a proprietary company it is necessary to have $2, two directors and two shareholders. In view of the wide- ranging use of proprietary companies, would he and the Government give consideration to ensuring that the capitalisation of these companies is such as to bear their responsibilities and that to do that may require some gearing within the companies' structure? The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Dumping of High Level Nuclear Waste in the Pacific

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to any proposals by the United States of America Environmental Protection Agency and Department of State to commence experimental dumping of high level nuclear waste in the Pacific Ocean in 1984; if so, can he say (a) what is the nature of high level wastes to be dumped, (b) what is their origin and (c) what is the proposed dumping site.
(2) Can he say whether the proposed dumping site is the same as that designated by the Japanese Government for the dumping of low level waste.
(3) What attitude has the Australian Government expressed to the United States Government concerning any such nuclear waste dumping proposals.
(4) Can he guarantee that Australian uranium exported to the United States will not be dumped in the Pacific Ocean as nuclear wastes derived from spent nuclear fuel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am advised that no consideration is being given by any regulatory agency in the United States of America for dumping high-level waste in the Pacific Ocean. Sea-dumping of high-level waste is prohibited by the United States Marine Protection Research and Sanctuaries Act of 1972. In addition, the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter of 1972, to which the United States is a signatory, declares high-level radioactive wastes as unsuitable for dumping at sea.

(3) The Australian Government has drawn to the attention of the United States resolutions of the South Pacific Forum, of which Australia is a member, expressing opposition to the dumping of nuclear wastes in the Pacific Ocean. These resolutions reflect the deep concern felt by the South Pacific countries about the dumping of radioactive waste in the Pacific.

(4) The question of the disposal of their nuclear waste is a domestic responsibility of individual countries as a part of the management of their nuclear power industries. However, in the light of the answers given to (1), (2) and (3) above Australia has no expectation that the United States will dump high -level nuclear wastes or other nuclear wastes unsuitable for dumping at sea in the Pacific Ocean, irrespective of whether or not such wastes are derived from Australian origin uranium or other nuclear materials.

(2) Has such a Ministerial Directive been issued; if so, does it depart in any way from the form recommended in Attachment A of the interim report; and (a) what are the details and (b) reasons for the variation.

(3) Has the Administrative Arrangements Order been amended in the terms recommended in Attachment B of the interim report; if not, (a) what terms have been amended and (b) what are the reasons for the variation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) Although the Ministerial Directive as issued incorporates a considerable number of editorial and stylistic changes, there are no substantive differences between it and that proposed in Attachment A to the interim report. For ease of reference, the Ministerial Directive as issued is here reproduced in full:
DIRECTIVE FROM THE PRIME MINISTER IN RESPECT OF THE MINISTER AND DEPARTMENT OF DEFENCE SUPPORT
Roles

1. The Minister for Defence has overall responsibility for the nation's defence policies. This is to include responsibility for policy development in respect of defence-related activities administered by the Minister for Defence Support. The Minister for Defence is to keep the Minister for Defence Support informed of policy developments affecting the defence-related activities administered by the latter and is to consult with him as appropriate.
2. The Minister for Defence Support is responsible for administering the following defence-related activities within the defence policies approved by the Minister for Defence:
the naval dockyards but not including fleet base activities at Garden Island Dockyard
the defence production factories
the defence research and development establishments
that part of defence purchasing that up until now has been under the control of the Minister for Administrative Services
defence industry development
marketing activities associated with the above together with related administrative functions.

3. In keeping with the intention that the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Support should work closely together, the Minister for Defence Support is also to occupy the position of Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence.

4. The Department of Defence Support is to participate in the policy development and the financial planning and programming processes of the Department of Defence in so far as they affect activities administered by the Minister for Defence Support.
Funding

5. The funding of the Department of Defence Support is to be decided as part of the Defence Outlay. Proposals for expenditure for the Department of Defence Support are to be subject to the same processes and to the same degree of scrutiny within the Department of Defence as other elements of defence expenditure. For this purpose the Department of Defence Support will make available to the Department of Defence all relevant information and documentation and the Department of Defence Support is to participate fully in the financial planning, programming and budget control processes of the Department of Defence. The form and content of the Appropriations for the Department of Defence Support shall be determined by the Departments of Defence, Defence Support and Finance.
Committees
6. The Minister for Defence Support and the Secretary to the Department of Defence Support are to be members of the Council of Defence.

7. The Secretary to the Department of Defence Support is to be a co-opted member of the Defence Committee when matters related to the activities administered by the Minister for Defence Support are to be considered.

8. In keeping with the requirements set out above concerning the relationship of the Department of Defence and the Department of Defence Support in respect of policy development processes and financial planning, programming and budget control processes, each department is to participate in the deliberations of the boards and committees of the other to an extent, and at a level to be agreed by the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Support.
Interdepartmental Access

9. The Department of Defence Support is to be responsive to appropriately endorsed requirements of the Defence Force. There is to be free access between the Department of Defence Support and the Service Offices in matters of a purely single Service nature. Involvement of Service personnel in activities administered by the Department of Defence Support is to be facilitated in the same way as it is in the Department of Defence.

10. In order effectively to discharge his responsibilities as set out in the Directive from the Minister of Defence to the Secretary to the Department of Defence regarding the position of the Chief Defence Scientist, the Chief Defence Scientist is to have free access to the research and development Laboratories which form part of the Department of Defence Support.
Annual Review

11. In keeping with the intention that the Secretary to the Department of Defence and the Secretary to the Department of Defence Support should work closely together, the Secretaries, together with the Chief of Defence Force Staff, are to meet regularly to review matters of common concern. In addition, in order to assess the effectiveness of the Defence Support organisation, a group of senior officers representing the Secretary to the Department of Defence , the Chief of Defence Force Staff and the Secretary to the Department of Defence Support, is to review annually the activities of the Department of Defence Support in respect of:
(a) defence production and dockyard support
(b) defence research and development
(c) defence purchasing
(d) defence industry development
(e) marketing of defence equipment and services.

12. The results of the annual review are to be presented by the Secretaries to the Departments of Defence and Defence Support to the Ministers for Defence and Defence Support and are to be included in the Annual Defence Report which is tabled in Parliament.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Selection of Conductors for ABC Orchestras

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 September:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the procedures followed in the selection of conductors for ABC orchestras.
(2) What person or group is responsible for interviewing and auditioning applicants.
(3) What procedures exist for reviewing selection decisions.
(4) How many people currently hold positions as conductors of ABC orchestras.
(5) How many are Australian-born.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information supplied by the Australian Broadcasting Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Conductors are selected by various methods.

(i) Chief or Principal conductors of the six symphony orchestras are selected by the Artists' Tours Committee (ATC), after extensive discussion and evaluation of their work. Any musician offered a Chief or Principal conductorship has normally undertaken at least one successful ABC concert tour, comprising concerts with several orchestras.

(ii) A certain number of longtime resident conductors, with proven ability, may be offered several concert engagements each year, after agreement by the Director of Music and the Federal Director of Concerts.

(iii) Individuals including visiting composer-conductors from overseas and returning Australian conductors often approach Music or Concert Department officers seeking engagements. Such conductors may be offered opportunities in line with their experience and particular areas of expertise.

(iv) Resident musicians with previous conducting experience outside the ABC may be invited to undertake an audition with one of the orchestras before a committee comprising principal players of the orchestra, the Chief or Principal conductor or a suitable alternative musician, and representatives of the Federal and State Music Departments. Full reports are provided after each audition. Successful auditionees are offered studio recording work and minor concerts to evaluate their abilities.

(2) The Artists' Tours Committee comprising senior officers of the ABC's Music and Concert Departments and chaired by the Assistant General Manager (Radio), or the Director of Music and Federal Director of Concerts.
(3) Visiting conductors who do not meet ABC, audience or critical expectations are not invited to undertake further tours.

Resident conductors who do not maintain their performance standards, who are unable to develop orchestra standards or whose appeal to audiences is perceived to be insufficiently positive are gradually phased out and replaced by younger or alternative residents. These decisions are made by the selection committee.
(4) Eight-the ABC administers six symphony orchestras, a training orchestra for young musicians (ABC Sinfonia) and employs a full-time Conductor-in-Residence.
(5) Three.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian National Railways Commission: Potential Public Service Obligations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 22 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many potential public service obligations has the Australian National Railways Commission identified for the Government for possible funding by revenue supplements under section 44 of the Australian National Railways Act.
(2) How many of the obligations have been accepted by the Government and for what reasons.
(3) What steps has the Government taken to accelerate the Commission's review of potential obligations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian National Railways Commission has currently identified one potential public service obligation for possible funding by a revenue supplement under Section 44 of the Australian National Railways Act.

(2) There has only been one specific request by the Commission under Section 44 of the Australian National Railways Act and this was accepted as a public service obligation while the future of the service was determined by arbitration .

(3) The Government considers that explicit funding of public service obligations is desirable in principle. Indeed, the new Australian National Railways Commission Bill makes specific provision for reimbursement of costs of complying with Government directions. It must be recognised, however, that the benefits of separate funding of PSOs are highly dependent upon the availability of accurate cost data.

The Government notes that the Commission is in the process of implementing its new computerised cost information sytstem and believes it would be more appropriate to defer explicit funding of public service obligations until that system is properly operational, and decisions can then be based on accurate cost data.
