ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bankcard Charges

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Bankcard charges up to 5 1/2 per cent on every transaction purchase with Bankcard, and this charge is levied from the retail outlets and others who accept the card for purchases so that, if a cardholder buys something worth $100, the bank takes up to $5.50 and only pays the retailer $94.50.

(2) Is it also a fact that many bankcard holders pay off their debts within a month, or at the most 2 months, of buying the goods or services on their card so that the period of credit actually given to the cardholder in these cases is only 1 or perhaps 2 months.

(3) If so, is it a fact that (a) the bank can then advance the credit to someone else and again collect up to 5 1/2 per cent on the next transaction, (b) the same credit may be turned over up to 10 or 12 times in a year and the corresponding fees, of up to 5 1/2 per cent, charged every time or on every transaction, and (c) the true rate of return to Bankcard can therefore be as high as 66 per cent per annum on the $100 committed, that is $5.50 x 12 turnovers.

(4) Will the Government (a) take action against the banks to prevent them making these disguised profits at will and (b) initiate a thorough investigation into Bankcard and other credit card systems, such as has been conducted in New Zealand recently, to assess the true profits made under these schemes and to evaluate the impact of the credit card revolution on our monetary system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that Bankcard banks levy a merchant service fee on the sellers of goods and services where sales have been financed by Bankcard. The fee is a service charge designed to cover, inter alia, the administrative costs incurred by the Bankcard organisation in processing transactions and the administrative and other costs (including provision for bad debts) incurred by participating banks in relation to Bankcard. The size of the charge to individual merchants is a matter for each bank to determine in negotiation with its customers. However, I am advised that the charges commonly fall in the range of 1 1/2 per cent to 5 1/2 per cent of the merchant's total Bankcard turnover, depending on his monthly volume of Bankcard sales and the average value of his Bankcard transactions.

(2) I am advised that it is not uncommon for Bankcard users to repay their outstanding balance within their period of charge free credit, which, depending on the juxtaposition of the date of purchase and the monthly billing date, may extend to nearly two months. However, many Bankcard users do not repay as promptly as this; the available data for amounts financed and advances outstanding under Bankcard (including cash advances) suggest that, on average, balances remain outstanding for around five months.

(3) It is possible for the set of transactions hypothesised in the question to occur under certain very restrictive assumptions about dates of purchase, dates of payment and details of the merchant Bankcard transactions. The resulting hypothetical fee income of $66 per annum for each $100 of revolving credit would represent revenue earned.

Profits to the Banks concerned would be substantially less than the revenue figures cited because, as noted in (1), the merchant service fee is a charge for services rendered and the cost of providing those services needs to be taken into account.

(4) The authorities carefully examined the operations of the Bankcard scheme prior to its introduction in 1974. Also, in July 1980 the Trade Practices Commission completed a detailed study of the operation of the Bankcard scheme. As a result, a number of anti-competitive elements in the agreements between member banks in the scheme were amended, including to provide that each bank must take its own decision on charges it makes to merchants and cardholders and on the period of free credit it allows cardholders. Restrictive conditions on the participation to the Bankcard scheme were also removed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tax Avoidance and Evasion

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to the revelations of the McCabe-Lafranchi report recently tabled in the Victorian Parliament and a statement by the Prime Minister that there needs to be amendments to the Companies Act to minimise tax abuse; if so, will the Attorney-General urgently review the need to strengthen the Companies Act if both corporate and tax abuse are to be minimised.
(2) Are there gaps in the Companies Act which lend themselves to tax abuse.
(3) In the light of the McCabe-Lafranchi report does the answer to Question No. 2866 (Hansard, 16 February 1982, pages 109-112) still apply.
(4) Would the provisions referred to in Question No. 2866 do much to strengthen the armoury in the battle against tax avoidance and evasion.

(5) Will the Attorney-General give urgent consideration to inserting in the Companies Act, as in force on 1 July 1982, the important and productive provisions set out in the Second Directive 68/151 on Co-ordination of Safeguards of the Council of the European Communities, which has recently been implemented and which has the force of law in the United Kingdom; if so, would the implementation of the under-mentioned provisions be critically important if the Companies Act is to play an important role in the battle against tax avoidance: 6 (minimum capital); 7 (non-cash consideration); 10 (non-cash consideration- valuing assets); 11 (promoters); 15 (payment of dividends); 17 (serious loss of capital); 25 (authorisation of new share issues); 27 (non-cash consideration); 29 (pre-emptive rights to new shares issues), and 35 (maintenance of capital).

(6) Has the Attorney-General's attention also been drawn to my repeated representations to the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs asking for a number of amendments to the Companies Act and the elimination of obvious errors; if so, will the Attorney-General re-consider the matters referred to in parts (7) to (16) of this question as the basis for possible amendment to the Act.
(7) Does section 81 of the Companies Act apply to a contract made by a person as agent or trustee for a company which the person wrongly believes to be incorporated; if so, why.

(8) Does sub-section 81 (11) apply to contracts within sub-section (1) which are not ratified; if so, is the effect of sub-section 81 (11) to exclude quasi- contractual remedies as well as contractual remedies.
(9) Does sub-section 81 (2) permit a company to ratify a contract notwithstanding that the parties to the contract have previously withdrawn from it or cancelled it.
(10) Bearing in mind sub-section 72 (1), can a class rights provision in a company memorandum be altered under sub-sections 125 (2), 126 (2) or 127 (2).
(11) If a company can alter a class rights clause in a memorandum, how can this be done, that is, by special or ordinary resolution.

(12) Once the class content has been obtained for a variation of rights contained in the (a) memorandum and (b) articles, does the company in general meeting then have to pass a resolution to alter the memorandum or the articles; if so, which sections of the Act require this to be done and what type of resolution, that is special or ordinary, is required to alter the (i) memorandum and (ii) articles.
(13) In sub-paragraph 129 (10) (h) (ii) should the reference to sub-section (9) be a reference to sub-section (12).
(14) Should sub-section 453 (1) and sub-section 453 (2) contain a provision similar to sub-paragraph 230 (1) (a) (iv).
(15) With respect to sections 33 to 37, should the Act include a requirement for all companies to raise and maintain a prescribed minimum nominal and paid-up capital; if not, why not.
(16) Has action been taken to remedy the defects in section 117 referred to in parts (12) to (16) of Question No. 3213; if not, why not and will urgent action now be taken.

(17) Is it a fact that if the provisions referred to in parts (7) to (16) remain as structured they constitute an open invitation to the corporate manipulator to make transactions to the detriment of a company and its creditors .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) While I am aware of the McCabe-Lafranchi report, I am not aware of any statement by the Prime Minister indicating a need for amendments to the Companies Act.

(3) to (5) I have directed my Department to undertake further work on the provisions referred to by the honourable member so that I can discuss the matter at an appropriate time in the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. The provisions referred to in item (5) of this question are the same as the articles set out in the answer to Question No. 2886. These provisions are also relevant to work that my Department will be doing to give effect to a decision by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities that the reforms made by the United Kingdom Companies Act 1980 in relation to maintenance of a company's capital, the issue of share capital, class rights and payment for share capital should be examined further in the context of an exposure draft of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill for enactment in 1984 or subsequent years. I have, however, noted the matters raised by the honourable member in questions 2866, 3212 and 4075. I will bear these matters in mind, to the extent that they remain relevant, in the consideration by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities of possible amendments to the co-operative companies and securities legislation.
(6) I have nothing to add to my answers to items (7) to (16) of this question.
(7) to (9) I have asked my Department to undertake further work on these items so that I can discuss the matter at an appropriate time in the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

(10) to (12) The honourable member will be aware of ss. 35 to 37 of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981 (see answer to items (17) to (22) of Question 3213). At its meeting in Sydney on 12 February 1982 the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities decided to defer a decision on a possible review of the provisions in the Companies Act 1981 relating to shareholder class rights (see in particular ss. 125, 126 and 127) pending a decision on whether or not to establish a Companies and Securities Law Review Committee.

(13) Section 94 of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1982 amended s-para 129 (10) (h) (ii) of the Companies Act 1981 so that the reference to sub- section (9) became a reference to sub-section (12).
(14) I have asked my Department to undertake further work on this item so that I can discuss the matter at an appropriate time in the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

(15) See answer to item (7) of Question 3213. The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities agreed at a meeting in Sydney on 12 February 1982 that the proposal raised by the honourable member should be examined further in the context of an exposure draft of the Companies and Securities Legislation ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill for enactment in 1984 or subsequent years.

(16) I am aware of the answer to items (12) to (16) of Question No. 3213 and of the answer to Question No. 4075. I understand that the matters raised by the honourable member in relation to s. 117 of the Companies Act 1981 have been discussed with advisers to State Ministers and representatives of the NCSC. These discussions have also considered various other proposals in relation to s. 117 that have been received from other persons. It is expected that the exposure draft of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 that will be placed later this year before the Ministerial Council for its consideration will contain possible amendments of s. 117.
(17) There is nothing that I would wish to add to the answers I have given to items (7) to (16) of this question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sports Development Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to concern in the community that this country' s 6 million registered sports participants are not being provided for in current Federal Government allocations, particularly in respect of the Sports Development Program.
(2) Has the Government considered direct allocations to be made to individual sporting bodies to encourage these bodies to program for the health and fitness of the Australian nation.
(3) Has the Government any tax policy that would allow tax rebates for large organisations that agree to underwrite or assist these programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the 1982-83 Budget, an amount of $3.7m was provided for Sports Assistance Programs. This Program incorporates, inter alia, what was previously the Sports Development Program. Of the $3.7m, $3.2m is for grants to national sporting organisations. The amount provided for this purpose in 1981-82 was $2. 9m.

(2) The question of criteria for allocating grants to particular sporting organisations is the responsibility of my colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, who is advised on this matter by the Sports Advisory Council.

(3) Section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the general deduction provision, authorises deductions for outgoings incurred in producing assessable income or necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining such income, except to the extent that the outgoings are of a capital, private or domestic nature. Businesses that sponsor or assist sporting programs may, therefore, be able to claim deductions for expenditure so incurred where it can be established, to the Commissioner's satisfaction, that an appropriate nexus (involving for example, publicity or goodwill) exists between the expenditure and the derivation of assessable income.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Independent Audit: Department of Employment and Industrial Relations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What independent audit is required by the Minister's Department to ensure the proper expenditure of funds granted to non-government organisations by the Minister or the Minister's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The following audit procedures apply to grants made by the Department to non- government organisations:
(a) The organisation is required to submit to the Department financial statements either on an annual basis or within a specified period.
(b) The statement must be audited by a qualified public accountant who is not an officer, member or employee of the organisation.
(c) Continued payment of on-going grants is subject to the receipt of vouchers or audited statements for the previous period.
(d) The organisation must certify that the conditions for which the grant has been made have been met.

Recipients of Bureau of Labour Market Research sponsored research grants are required to provide statements of expenditure fully supported by receipts or vouchers in lieu of independent audit requirement at (b).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mr H. M. Miller: Corporate Activities in Long Bay Gaol

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to recent Press articles relating to the alleged continued corporate activities of company director, Mr H . M. Miller, currently serving a prison sentence in Long Bay Gaol.

(2) Does section 227 of the Companies Act prohibit a company director from being a director of, or otherwise taking part in, the management of a company whilst in prison; if not, will the Attorney-General take immediate steps to ensure that such company directors are prohibited from acting in this capacity whilst in prison.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of some of the Press articles in question. The New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission has provided the following information in relation to this matter:

(a) Mr Miller was convicted on five counts of aiding and abetting Computicket Australia Pty Ltd to breach section 178A of the N.S.W. Crimes Act 1900. On 7 May 1982 Mr Miller was sentenced to 3 years imprisonment with a non-parole period expiring on 28 February 1983.

(b) According to Companies Forms 43 lodged with the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission on 8 June 1982, Mr Miller resigned as a director of Harry M. Miller and Company Pty Ltd, Harry M. Miller Attractions (Aust.) Pty Ltd and Densate Pty Ltd on 7 May 1982.
(c) The New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission has no evidence to suggest that Mr Miller has taken part in the management of any of these companies while serving his sentence in jail.

(2) The policy in relation to section 227 of the Companies Act 1981 has been under consideration in the context of the planned exposure draft of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983. It is hoped that the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities will later this year agree to this exposure draft being made available for public comment. While the current version of the exposure draft does not contain any amendments to section 227, the Attorney-General's Department has been directed to ensure that when the public comments on the exposure draft are being examined, consideration is given to the matters raised by the honourable member in relation to section 227.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sales Tax Exemptions: Fermented Fruit Juices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister Assisting the Treasurer in March 1977 acknowledge that exemption from sales tax would be reviewed for fermented fruit juices other than grape wine when further sales tax exemptions were being considered as a result of previous requests and the representations of the Member for Wide Bay on behalf of Mr J. Gianduzzo who, since 1972 and trading as Tropical Wines in Bundaberg, Queensland, has annually produced 8,200 gallons of non-grape wines unique in Australia.

(2) Has the Government increased sales tax twice since 1975 on these products, from 15 percent to 20 percent, despite Mr Gianduzzo's appeals each time, while leaving grape wine and apple cider exempt each time.
(3) Did the Government reject these representations in framing the 1978-79 budget for fiscal reasons without giving any other justification for the inequity of the position.

(4) Has Mr Gianduzzo co-operated fully with Australian Taxation Office inquiries as to his costs, income and turnover, and established to their satisfaction that he is providing an attraction to tourists, including those spending foreign currency, and producing a product which conforms with standards required for grape wines including alcohol content.

(5) Is he able to say whether the Gianduzzo family has worked efficiently from 8 am to 7 pm, 7 days a week, 363 days a year for a return well below that of sugar mill, bar, retailing or other award workers so that their enterprise is threatened while they still sell quality products at prices lower before sales tax, but higher after sales tax, than those of large wine enterprises enjoying total sales tax exemption.

(6) Did he again promise a review when sales taxes were next reviewed in his reply to me of 14 January 1982 and acknowledge the existence of anomalies and the need to correct them carefully to avoid creating more unspecified anomalies and to consider other unspecified factors.

(7) Has the Government's review on each occasion since 1977 aggravated the anomalies, the existence of which it acknowledges, by increasing sales tax on the products of tropical wines but not on grape wine and apple cider.

(8) Has the Government exempted from sales tax under item 36 of the First Schedule, Division VI of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act: stout; cider; non-alcoholic fruit juice beverages; vermouths and aperitifs; apricot and other fruit juice essence cocktails; manhattan cocktail and martini cocktail made by McWilliams Wine Pty Ltd; apricot, banana, cherry, maraschino and pineapple wine cocktails made by Chateau Rosevale; banana and prunella cocktails made by Hamiltons Ewell Vineyards Pty Ltd; Brandivino, an Australian wine with imported additives; Norman Golden Glow apricot, cherry and pineapple cocktails, and Stonyfell apricot and cherry wine cocktails.

(9) Will he (a) give Mr Gianduzzo reasons for this discrimination, (b) define any new anomalies that could possibly arise if a prompt favorable determination was made and (c) respond relevantly to my request of 5 February 1982 for definition of the other factors to be considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes, but the increase in sales tax on fruit wines resulted from general across-the-board increases in rates. In the 1981 and 1982 Budgets all sales tax rates were increased by 2.5 percentage points so that goods previously taxable at 15 percent became taxable at 17.5 percent as from 19 August 1981 and taxable at 20 percent as from 18 August 1982. As fermented fruit juices were amongst those goods affected by the general across-the-board increase in rates it was not practicable to consider their position in isolation from all other goods that were previously taxable at the same rate as fermented fruit juices.

These general increases in rates did not apply to exempt goods such as grape wine and apple cider produced in Australia. However, the rate of tax on imported grape wine and cider increased in line with locally produced fermented fruit juices.

(3) In framing the 1978-79 Budget the Government gave consideration to a wide range of representations for tax relief or other form of assistance. It was not a question of the Government rejecting these representations including those of Mr Gianduzzo but whether in the context of the overall Budget it was possible to grant some form of tax relief and, if so, what form it was to take.
(4) The Commissioner of Taxation informs me that he is not aware of any lack of co-operation on the part of Mr Gianduzzo.
(5) I am not personally aware of Mr Gianduzzo's work situation but the point has been made to me in representations on the matter.
(6) Yes.
(7) I have explained the Government's position in my answer to question 2.
(8) The goods referred to relate to decisions made by the Commissioner of Taxation under item 36 and are contained in the publication titled Sales Tax Exemptions and Classifications.

(9) (a) There is no discrimination in favour of the products listed in question 8 as against those produced by Mr Gianduzzo. With the exception of stout and cider, all of the alcoholic products ruled to be exempt are made principally of grape wine and references to apricot, banana, cherry pineapple indicate the kind of flavourings added. These products are not fruit wines of the kind produced by Mr Gianduzzo. Stout is exempt under item 36 (1), being a beer while cider is specifically exempted by item 36 (2). Wines produced from fruits other than the grape or from other products such as honey (mead) or rice (saki) are taxable.

(b) If fruit wines were to be exempted, the exemption would have to apply to both the imported and local product to avoid infringing the GATT. This could have repercussions in relation to the discrimination between local wines and overseas wines and also the existing sales tax discrimination between beer and cider of local and overseas origin. Those of Australian origin were exempted prior to Australia becoming a party to the GATT. The exemption of imported products would reduce the element of protection at present enjoyed by Australian beer, wine and cider because of their exemption.

(c) Other factors that need to be taken into account by the Government include the overall incidence of taxation including excise duty, customs duty and income tax and the general economic position of the industry. Wine producers, for example, incurred substantial income tax liabilities as a result of a change in the valuation of wine stocks some years ago and are only now recovering from that change.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Atomic Energy Commission: Reprocessing of Aluminium Fuel Elements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 22 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to pages 51 and 52 of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's annual report for 1965-66 where it is stated that it had been necessary to reprocess several hundred aluminium fuel elements containing a total of one kilogram of uranium 233 used in physics experiments; that some of these elements had become swollen and defective and all were becoming difficult to handle because of the increasing radiation levels due to daughter products of the contained uranium 233; that, a small laboratory- scale recycle facility was built and operated to produce decontaminated uranium dioxide for refabrication into new fuel elements, and that reprocessing and reconversion had been completed with a loss of approximately 1 per cent of uranium 233.

(2) In view of the Minister's answer to Question No. 4469 (Hansard, 18 August 1982, pages 669-70), what were the physics experiments in which the aluminium fuel elements referred to in part (1) were used.
(3) What volume of material has been reprocessed and reconverted in the recycle facility referred to in part (1), or any other facility, at Lucas Heights, NSW.
(4) What is the volume and nature of any materials (a) extracted and (b) stockpiled as a result of reprocessing and reconversion of this kind.
(5) What is the volume and nature of any waste materials produced and what practice was adopted for the disposal of material of this kind.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The answer to Question No. 4469 referred specifically to spent fuel elements from the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights and has no bearing on this question.

The physics experiments referred to in the AAEC's Annual Report for 1965-66 were part of a program initiated in 1963-64 to obtain basic neutron data on the behaviour of various fuel moderator mixtures in high temperature gas cooled reactors. These experiments were also referred to in the AAEC's Annual Reports for 1963-64 (pages 34, 35) and 1964-65 (pages 38 and 40).

For the purpose of these experiments, one kg of U233, containing small amounts of U232 as an impurity, was obtained on lease from the USA and fabricated into fuel elements. Two sets of experiments were carried out, using the AAEC's MOATA reactor. In the first, sub-critical fuel assemblies (simulating conditions in a full, cold, reactor core) provided a means to check nuclear data and test methods of computing reactor core characteristics. In the second, samples representative of reactor core composition and sufficiently large to establish the reactor's nuclear properties were placed within MOATA to measure neutron reaction rates.
(3) See (2). Initially the one kg of U233 was fabricated into 205 fuel elements , each containing an average of 4.85 grams of U233.

Fission product activity in the U233 was negligible because all experiments were carried out at extremely low level fission rates. However, as the decay of U232 present in the U233 resulted in the growth of daughter products and increasing levels of gamma radiation, and also because during the experiments a small number of fuel elements had suffered damage, in 1966 all these fuel elements were processed to remove the radioactivity arising from the decay of U232 and the recovered uranium oxide was refabricated. 177 fuel elements were fabricated, averaging 5.05 grams of U233, as well as 20 half plates and 2 quarter plates. In 1967 the entire batch of elements was processed a second time in order to reduce the radioactivity arising from the growth of the decay products from U232, so that the material could be conveniently transported to the USA at the termination of the lease.
There has been no other reprocessing and reconversion of fuel elements at this or any other facility at Lucas Heights. The facility used for processing the U233 has been dismantled.
(4) (a) Overall recovery of uranium present after dissolution was about 98 per cent.
(b) None of the U233 was stockpiled: it was returned to the lessor in 1967.

(5) Solid waste containing 3.45g of U233 was obtained from treatment of processing solutions, and a further 3.34g of U233 are stored in solution. The solid waste has been placed in storage facilities at Lucas Heights. Contaminated solid materials such as gloves, tissues, equipment, aluminium powder and graphite containing 16.06g of U233 are also held in storage facilities at Lucas Heights, whilst contaminated materials containing a further 4.04g of U233 were disposed of in the Little Forest burial ground prior to its closure in 1968.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Commonwealth Government has, for some time, recognised the need for combined Federal/State initiatives in the enforcement and prevention of crime.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Fluoridation of Water

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the report of a Committee to the Quebec Minister of the Environment on 30 November 1979.
(2) If so, does the report confirm the mutagenicity of fluoridated water, with increased cancer mortality, and recommend suspension of fluoridation and further evaluation of the risks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No. The report contains no convincing evidence that fluoridation of water increases mutagenicity and mortality from cancer. It recommends the suspension of a Bill dealing with compulsory fluoridation in Quebec until fluoridation has been subjected to further investigation.

With regard to mutagenicity, the extensive report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Fluoridation of Victorian Water Supplies (1980) summarises reports of studies in Britain in 1958 and 1962, and in the United States of America in 1974 and 1976, which show no association between water fluoridation and the incidence of congenital malformations. Details of a further investigation in England, which also shows no such association, were published in 'Community Medicine': 2. p.190, 1980.

The allegation of a link between fluoridation of water and cancer led to a number of investigations all of which show no association between fluoridation and cancer. These investigations were carried out in the United States of America, United Kingdom, Canada, New Zealand and Australia (New South Wales).

An investigation throughout Canada which was conducted by the Canadian Department of National Health and Welfare was completed in 1978. It was concluded that '. . . the maintenance of the fluoride level of potable water at approximately 1 mg/L is the most efficient procedure to decrease the incidence of dental caries, and such a level of fluoride poses no risk to the health of Canadians'.
Fluoridation of water in Quebec is continuing though it is no longer mandatory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States of America Ports: Access to Nuclear-armed and/or Nuclear-powered Ships

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether any cities in the United States of America deny access to their ports to nuclear armed and/or nuclear-powered ships; if so, (a) what cities, and (b) on what grounds is access denied.

(2) Is he also able to say whether any countries involved in the NATO alliance refuse access to their ports to nuclear-powered and/or nuclear-armed ships; if so, (a) which countries and (b) on what grounds is access denied.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am informed that no cities in the United States of America deny access to their ports by United States Navy ships in the categories mentioned. However, some ports in the United States are not visited by conventional or nuclear- powered warships either because there is no operational requirement to do so or because of particular port characteristics such as channel depth, accessibility, port services, and so on. These requirements are assessed by national, not local authorities. The criteria employed by the United States authorities in deciding visits by United States Navy nuclear-powered ships to United States domestic ports are identical with those employed for visits to foreign ports.

(2) I am informed that no NATO country imposes a blanket ban on visits by nuclear-powered warships. Requests for port entry are handled bilaterally between the governments concerned on a case-by-case basis employing safety and environmental criteria corresponding to those introduced by Australia in 1976. Visits by nuclear-armed ships are permitted by most NATO countries. However, I understand that Denmark and Norway maintain policies of not permitting the stationing of nuclear weapons in their territory in peace time and look to other governments to respect their nuclear policies. The United States, Britain and France follow a policy of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons in particular ships.

Government House-Official Secretary to the Governor-General, Deputy Official Secretary to the Governor-General, Administrative Secretary to the Governor- General, Director Honours Secretariat.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act: Use of Suspension Provisions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On how many occasions, and in what departments, have the suspension provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1977 been implemented since the Act came into operation.
(2) How many persons have been suspended under the Act and for what length of time was each suspended.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Public Service Board, having consulted with the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, has informed me that the suspension provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1977 have been used nine times in Commonwealth employment. The details of the use of the Act are as follows:

(a) Some 120 members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees' Association employed in the Australian Telecommunications Commission, were suspended from duty for the period 13-17 July 1979 for implementing work bans in support of a wage claim.

(b) 1132 Transport Workers' Union members were suspended in the period 21-31 July 1981 in the Departments of Administrative Services, Capital Territory, Defence, Housing and Construction, National Development and Energy, and Transport. The suspensions, which were issued over industrial action taken in support of a pay claim, were subsequently cancelled.

(c) 638 members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association and 343 members of the Australian Public Service Association (Fourth Division Officers) employed in the Australian Telecommunications Commission were suspended from duty for the period 22-26 July 1981 in connection with the implementation of work bans in support of a pay claim.

(d) 480 members of the Licensed Aircraft Engineers' Association employed in Trans-Australia Airlines were suspended from duty for the period 14-17 August 1981 in connection with strike action taken in support of a pay claim.

(e) Approximately 90 broadcasting engineering officers employed in the Australian Broadcasting Commission were suspended from 14 to 17 August 1981 for engaging in strike action over a pay claim. In addition, some 230 other employees in the Australian Broadcasting Commission were stood down during the course of the dispute because they could not be gainfully employed.

(f) 26 members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees' Association employed in the Australian Telecommunications Commission at the Haymarket Exchange were suspended from 2-14 December 1981 for implementing work bans in connection with a staffing dispute. 13 other staff at the Exchange were stood down during the course of the dispute.

(g) During the period 7-17 December 1981, a total of 451 members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association employed in the Department of Social Security were suspended for implementing work bans in support of staffing claims. Suspensions were progressively lifted from 11 December and the final 414 were lifted on 17 December 1981.

(h) Some 640 Transport Workers' Union members were suspended from duty in the period 11-24 December 1981 for engaging in industrial action in support of a pay claim. The Departments of the Capital Territory, Administrative Services and Housing and Construction were affected, as were the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority and the Capital Territory Health Commission.

(i) Approximately 2240 members of the Australian Capital Territory Teachers' Federation employed in the Commonwealth Teaching Service were suspended from duty during the period 12-17 March 1982 for engaging in industrial action in support of a pay claim.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement Act: Voluntary Retirement Provisions

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What sum has been spent in payments under the voluntary retirement provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979, to staff affected by the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions involving the transfer to the private sector of functions previously performed in the Australian Public Service.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Conference on Disarmament: Visas for Delegates

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to problems some Australian delegates had in obtaining visas to attend the recent United Nations conference on Disarmament in New York, USA.
(2) Did he receive any requests for assistance in obtaining visas for delegates .
(3) If so, what approach was made to the US Government and what was the response.
(4) Is he able to say whether the Australian delegate's applications for visas were treated in the same way as any other application.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) No approach was made to the United States Government. Under the terms of the Headquarters Agreement signed between the United States and the United Nations, the United States undertook not to impose any impediment on the transit to the United Nations Headquarters district of representatives of non- governmental organisations recognised by the United Nations for the purpose of consultations under Article 71 of the Charter. Those Australians and other individuals refused visas to the United States were not representatives of such organisations.

In these circumstances the issue of visas is a matter for the United States to decide. It would not be appropriate for the Australian Government to suggest to the United States the manner in which they should exercise their responsibilities.
(4) The Government has not reason to believe that applications for visas by Australian citizens were treated any differently from those lodged by citizens of other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Employees of the Northern Territory Government are not employees of the Commonwealth. If the number of Commonwealth and Northern Territory Government employees are added together the growth over the period is as stated; this was indicated in my answer to Question No. 4695 in Hansard of the House of Representatives on 21 September 1982.

(2) The Public Service Board has advised me that it does not hold comprehensive information on movements of functions between all Commonwealth and State bodies. It advises, however, that in the period under review, for those departments and statutory authorities under ceiling control, the following transfers of functions between the Commonwealth and States took place:
(i) 137 staff of the Australian Legal Aid Office were transferred to the Legal Aid Commissions of South Australia, Queensland and Victoria, and
(ii) 9350 staff transferred from State Rail Authorities to Australian National Railways.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Funding for Pre-schools

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security , upon notice, on 9 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the 'block grant' method of Commonwealth funding for pre-schools resulted in an effective shortfall of over $15m in 1981-82.
(2) Will the Minister undertake to review the sum currently made available for pre-schooling with a view to increasing it substantially.
(3) Can the Minister also give an assurance that funding for pre-schooling will be adequately indexed in future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The Commonwealth has accepted the view, put with considerable emphasis by the States, that the basic responsibility for pre-school education lies with the States. This financial support, which is additional to the general purpose revenue grants, is provided to the State Governments in the form of a block grant and may be applied by the States according to their own assessment of priorities. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tax Concessions for Interest on Home Loans

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the calls of some State Premiers for the Federal Government to exempt interest paid on home loans from assessable income tax paid by individuals and the Government's investigation of options for relieving the home loan repayment burdens placed on current home buyers as a consequence of high interest rates, has the Government estimated the revenue which would be forgone in 1980-81 by tax exemptions on:
(a) full mortgage interest payments of all home purchasers,
(b) full mortgage interest payments of first home buyers and
(c) one-third of the mortgage interest payments of first home buyers whose assessable income is less than $20,000.
(2) If so, what are those estimates.
(3) If not, will he have such estimates made and provide them to the Parliament to facilitate informed debate about the options for relieving home loan repayment burdens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) As the honourable member will be aware the Government introduced legislation earlier this year to assist home buyers who first occupied a home after 1 July 1977. The scheme provides a rebate on home loan interest payments in the first year of occupancy up to a limit of $700 where there is a dependent child or dependent student or $500 where there is no dependent child or dependent student, the rebate entitlement reducing by $100 per year over the succeeding four years.

Following on a further decision announced in the Budget, more recent legislation has extended the home loan interest rebate to others in respect of interest that exceeds 10 per cent per annum on up to $60,000 of a loan. The rebate under both schemes is at the standard rate of tax and applies to home interest payments after 1 July 1982. Where a taxpayer meets the criteria for a rebate under both schemes the scheme which confers the larger rebate will apply.
The full-year cost to income tax revenue of allowing deductions in respect of home loan interest payments is estimated as follows:

$m (a) Full mortgage interest payments of all home purchases 1,565 (b) Full mortgage interest payments of first home buyers 915 (c) One-third of mortgage interest payments of first home buyers whose assessable income is less than $20, 000 150

These estimates are based on estimated levels of home loan interest payments in the 1982-83 income year. The cost of the existing home loan interest rebate schemes has not been offset against the estimates.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Small Arms Factory, Lithgow

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Support, upon notice, on 21 April, 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the import restrictions that prevent the importation of military -type automatic rifles, why is the Small Arms Factory at Lithgow, N.S.W., engaged in a sales promotion program designed to sell similar weapons to the Australian public.
(2) Were these weapons manufactured for the Department of Defence.
(3) How many weapons is it proposed to sell to Australians.
(4) Does the Government consider the proliferation of this type of weapons in the public interest.
(5) What is the availability of ammunition for this type of weapon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Small Arms Factory at Lithgow is not engaged in a sales promotion program designed to sell military-type automatic rifles to the Australian public . Since 1978 sales of self-loading rifles have been permitted on the request of members of the public only when the buyer has proven authorisation under relevant State or Territorial laws to buy and own such a weapon.

(3) As from 1 September 1982 rifles can only be made available for sale to registered rifle club members. Their future requirements are not known, however I would estimate the quantity to be less than 30 per annum.

(4) Gun control legislation is vested in the States and Territory and public interest is more correctly expressed through State Legislature. The Government does not consider that sales of rifles to registered rifle club members represents a proliferation of this type of weapon.
(5) Ammunition manufactured to military specification in Government factories is made available only to members of the National Rifle Association and to licenced dealers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation: Deduction for Soil Conservation Expenditure

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard, 5 May 1982, page 2232) where he stated that the Government had legislated to allow expenditure undertaken by an individual farmer on soil conservation to be deducted in the year of expenditure instead of over 10 years, does the tax deduction referred to also apply to laser land forming in view of the fact that it is an important soil and water conservation measure in certain irrigation areas; if not, why not .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The question of income tax deductions allowable for expenditure incurred by a primary producer on soil conservation is governed by section 75D of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Section 75D authorises an immediate deduction for the cost which a farmer incurs in constructing surface or sub-surface drainage works for the purpose of controlling salinity or assisting in drainage control on farmland , except where the work consists of the drainage of a swamp or low-lying land.

Land forming or levelling in irrigation areas to improve drainage of irrigation water, whether or not such work is carried out using laser equipment, is generally regarded as being for the purpose of controlling or combating salinity in the land or a potential salinity problem and, therefore, eligible for immediate deduction under section 75D.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Generally speaking there is no legal requirement that Australian residents employed in Australia by foreign companies operating in Australia be paid their salaries or wages in Australia. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised, however, that the view is taken that salaries and wages of Australian residents employed in Australia by a foreign company have their source in Australia and are therefore assessable to Australian tax whether or not they are paid in Australia. Inspections are made of employers' records to ensure that they are complying with the PAYE provisions of the income tax law .
(3) The Commissioner has not expressed any general concern. He is, of course, obliged by section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to preserve confidentiality in respect of specific cases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 19 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement by Mr Les Richardson, Chairman of the Vegetable Council of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, claiming that there has been a substantial cut-back in the plantings of green beans, peas, cauliflower and broccoli in Tasmania; if so, can he say whether the cut-backs are associated with negotiations with the New Zealand Government for closer economic relations.
(2) Can he say whether General Jones Ltd or Gordon Edgell Pty Ltd or any of their affiliated companies have vegetable processing operations in New Zealand.
(3) Can he say whether the reduced vegetable production in Tasmania might be taken up by increased imports from New Zealand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (3) The Department of Primary Industry has made enquiries into reports of some reduction in the area of vegetables contracted for processing purposes in Tasmania. The Department is satisfied that there is no link between the changes in the area contracted for vegetables in Tasmania and the arrangements for closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand.

Most vegetable products of importance for Tasmania are already free of duty or subject only to the minimal tariffs if imported from New Zealand. In these circumstances the agreement achieved with New Zealand for an accelerated removal of its export subsidy arrangements for peas, beans, sweet corn and potato products and for a phasing out of export subsidies on all other products from 1985 to 1987, should result in an improvement in the relative competitiveness of Tasmania's vegetable growing and processing industries vis-a-vis New Zealand.

(2) I am advised that the only affiliation between Australian and New Zealand vegetable processors is the operation of a single frozen vegetable processing plant by Petersville Australia Limited in New Zealand through its international branch, Petersville International Limited. The plant is situated in Blenheim in the South Island and I understand is geared mainly to supplying the New Zealand market and export markets other than Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Population Estimates

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to 'Population estimates and projections of local government areas in Western Sydney: an analysis of the issues' by Donald Perlgut of the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils.
(2) Will he ask the Australian Bureau of Statistics to comment on it.
(3) Will he ask the Bureau to undertake a study of under-enumeration in census data associated with non-English speaking residents, especially in the Fairfield City Council area.

(4) Is there any substance to the claim on page 16 of the paper that Fairfield City Council has forgone $135,000 of Commonwealth revenue funds during the last 5 years because of under-estimation of population.
(5) If the claim is correct can an adjustment be made by way of an ex-gratia payment or an adjustment in the next allocation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) is currently investigating some of the matters raised in the paper, and will provide comments directly to the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils in the near future.

(3) No. I am informed that the ABS conducted an Australia-wide evaluation survey soon after the 1981 Census for the purpose of measuring under-enumeration in the Census. An analysis of the data from this survey is understood to have shown that, overall, there is no significant difference in census under- enumeration between Australian-born and overseas-born persons.

I am also informed that special efforts were made in the 1981 Census-in the Fairfield City Council area as well as other areas with large numbers of migrants-to produce an accurate enumeration of persons born overseas. These efforts are considered to have been successful as the results of the evaluation survey show that only a very small percentage of persons was missed in the Census.

(4) As far as the Commonwealth's local government tax sharing funds are concerned, the allocation between local authorities within a State is related, among other things, to the population of each authority. Since estimates of the population in the Fairfield City Council area would need to be compared with estimates of the population derived on the same basis in other local government jurisdictions in New South Wales, it is not possible to comment on the substance of the claim concerning $135,000 foregone by the Fairfield City Council.

(5) Under the local government tax sharing arrangemens, the Commonwealth provides funds to each State government on the basis of a set formula. Each State is then responsible for the allocation of the funds between the local authorities within its borders. The question of any additional payments to individual local authorities is therefore a matter for consideration by the State government concerned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tullamarine Airport: Membership of Committee

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information is he able to provide on the achievements of the joint Victorian/Federal Government Committee established by his predecessor in 1980 to establish Tullamarine Airport as the main gateway to Australia for international air travel.
(2) What are the names and classifications of the past and present membership of the committee.
(3) On what occasions has the committee met.
(4) What recommendations has the committee made to the Government and what action has been taken in respect of each recommendation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the meeting in December 1980, the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, agreed to a proposal made by the former Premier of Victoria, Mr Hamer, that a joint committee be established to monitor progress made in encouraging international airlines to provide a better balance of services between Melbourne and Sydney. No such committee was subsequently established, although Mr Hunt did write to all international airlines serving Melbourne, asking them to consider the possibility of increasing their use of Melbourne Airport within their approved levels of services to Australia.
(2) to (4) Not applicable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Polychlorinated Biphenyls: Use by Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What materials and equipment currently in use in the Minister's Department or bodies under the Minister's control are known to contain polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the dangers associated with the use of PCBs.

(3) What (a) statutory and (b) advisory conditions exist for the purpose of monitoring all introduction, use, transport and disposal of PCBs, and what arrangements are currently in existence for policing statutory conditions.
(4) What methods of storage and disposal are used for materials and equipment containing PCBs when those items become redundant or useless.

(5) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to any contamination of the environment by PCBs which may be wholly or partly due to the use, etc., of PCBs by the Minister's Department or bodies under the Minister's control; if so, what are the details.

(6) Has the Minister taken any steps to ensure that all employees under the Minister's control are fully aware of the dangers of PCBs; if so, what are the details; if not, will the Minister now do so; if the Minister will not do so, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No materials or equipment currently in use in the Department of Social Security or bodies under my control are known to contain polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).
(2) Yes.
(3) to (6) As no PCBs are known to be in use in my Department or bodies under my control these parts of the question are not applicable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Polychlorinated Biphenyls: Monitoring of Environmental Contamination

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 27 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of existing arrangements for the monitoring of environmental contamination by polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).

(2) What are the details for each incident of PCB contamination occurring in each year since 1970-71, giving (a) dates, (b) locations, (c) amounts, (d) effects on (i) human health and (ii) the environment, (e) costs of clean-up operations and (f) any follow-up (i) health and (ii) environmental monitoring which has taken place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The responsibility for monitoring environmental contamination by PCBs or any other hazardous chemical is that of State authorities.
(2) I do not have the information requested. Such information would be held by State authorities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Employment Statistics

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the figures for employment derived from the Commonwealth Census of 30 June 1981 be published.

(2) In the event that the figures are published before an answer is provided to part (1) of this question what (a) are the numbers of persons employed in manufacturing in each Commonwealth Electoral Division and (b) percentage of the total labour force in each Electoral Division does this figure constitute.
(3) What are the (a) national, (b) state and (c) territorial statistics for employment in manufacturing expressed (i) in figures and (ii) as a percentage of the total workforce in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Employment figures from the 1981 Census have been available, on microfiche, since July 1982.

(2) Statistics on the numbers of persons employed in manufacturing industry in each Commonwealth Electoral Division (CED) at 30 June 1981 are included in microfiche batch 81.208, 'Small Area Data-Commonwealth Electoral Divisions', a copy of which is available in the Parliamentary Library. These fiche also contain information on the total labour force in each CED. The percentage of the total labour force in each CED, employed in manufacturing, can be derived from these figures.

(3) Statistics on the numbers of persons employed in manufacturing industry at the national, State and Territory levels are included in microfiche batch 81.303 , 'Small Area Data-States and Australia'. These fiche also contain information on the total labour force at the national, State and Territory levels. The percentage of the total labour force in the States, Territories and Australia employed in manufacturing can be derived from these figures.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Unemployment Rates in Ethnic Communities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What surveys have been carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, or what other statistical material is available to the Bureau, which compares unemployment rates in various ethnic communities in Australia, for example (a) Yugoslav, (b) Greek, (c) Italian, (d) Maltese, (e) Polish, (f) German, (g) Dutch , (h) Jewish, (j) Lebanese, (k) Vietnamese and (l) Chinese.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Statistics of unemployment rates classified by country of birth are compiled from the Bureau's monthly labour force survey and published in 'The Labour Force , Australia' (Catalogue No. 6203.0). Unemployment rates for persons born in Yugoslavia, Greece, Italy, Malta, Poland, Germany, the Netherlands and Lebanon are shown in this publication. Estimates for persons born in Vietnam or China are not available, nor is information available from the labour force survey on the Jewish community.

Information on unemployment rates by country of birth is also available from the 1981 Census of Population and Housing; see table 7 in microfiche batch 81. 501, a copy of which is available in the Parliamentary Library. As regards the Jewish community, information that may be of interest will be a cross- classificatory table of religion and labour force status, expected to become available for the whole of Australia towards the end of 1983.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation Evasion and Avoidance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to my question without notice of 28 October 1982 (Hansard, page 2703) requesting him to take immediate steps to set up within the Australian Taxation Office its own legal division to ensure that the Office will be self-sufficient and accountable in the field of taxation litigation and recovery, can he intimate (a) whether he has discussed the matter with the Commissioner for Taxation and (b) when he will take steps to set up within the Taxtion Office its own legal division.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) As I said on 28 October 1982 in answer to the honourable member, I have raised this matter with the Commissioner of Taxation. The Commissioner is examining the implications of the proposal which, as the honourable member will realise, involves issues which would need to be resolved in consultation with the Public Service Board and the Attorney-General's Department. It is not a matter which can, or should, be decided hurriedly.
